title: mummified children found deep inside
story: NewsMummied children found deep inside ,-year-old tomb in EgyptEgyptian archaeologists found  mummied children and over  adults at the Tuna El-Gebel site south of CairoShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsSome of the mummies were found wrapped in linen in burial chambers "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwelve mummied children have been discovered inside a ,-year-old Pharaonic tomb in Egypt that likely holds the bodies of high-ranking officials. Egyptian archaeologists found  mummies dating back to -BC, the Ptolemaic era, at the Tuna El-Gebel site in Minya. The mummies, including  children, were in four burial chambers ft deep inside the tomb south of Cairo, said Egypts antiquities ministry. Some were in stone coffins or wooden sarcophagi, while others were wrapped in linen, the government said. It is likely the people held important positions during the Ptolemaic era, when a Macedonian Greek royal family ruled Ptolemaic Kingdom in Egypt.   The familys rule lasted  years - ending with the apparent suicide of Cleopatra VII as the kingdom fell to Rome - and they were ancient Egypts last dynasty. The identities of the mummies were still unknown, said Mostafa Waziri, secretary-general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities. He said: We have not found names written in hieroglyphics.   He said it was obvious from the mummication method that the iniduals whose remains were found had to some extent held important or prestigious positions. Forty of the mummies were displayed during an announcement ceremony attended by ambassadors from several countries. The archaeological finding was the first of .  It was unearthed through a joint mission with the Research Centre for Archaeological Studies of Minya University. Last month, experts revealed they had finally solved one of the mysteries of King Tutankhamuns tomb as it was painstakingly restored by experts. An international team of conservators spent  years bringing the ,-year-old, decaying tomb - once said to be cursed - back to its former glory.  Over the last decade, experts stabilised wall paintings that decorate the boy-kings chamber, installed barriers and set up a ventilation system to reduce damage to the site. They also spent time investigating mysterious brown spots that were growing on wall paintings inside the tomb where the Pharaohs mummied body was discovered by British Egyptologist Howard Carter in  The brown spots were feared to be growing like a fungus, but conservators confirmed that the spots were microbes that were long dead.

title: worlds oldest woman who didnt
story: NewsWorlds oldest woman who didnt enjoy single day in long le dies aged Koku Istambulova said she did nothing special to live so long and was laughing with her grandchildren when she diedShareCommentsByWill StewartKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video worlds-oldest-woman-aged--,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman believed to be the oldest person to have ever lived has died aged . Koku Istambulova, a survivor of Stalin’s repressions, would have turned  in June, according to accepted pension records in Russia. She was older than a woman listed in the Russian Book of Records who died last month supposedly aged , officials believed. Koku made headlines last year by saying she had never lived a single happy day in her long le. Her grandson Iliyas Abubakarov said she had supper as usual on Sunday, January  at her village home in Chechnya.   “She was joking, she was talking,” he said. “Then she suddenly felt unwell, she complained of a chest pain.“We called the doctor, we were told that her blood pressure had dropped, and injections were made.“But they failed to save her. She died in a quiet way, fully conscious, praying.” She has been buried in her home village Bratskoe, survived by five grandchildren and  great grandchildren. A Muslim who was born before the last Tsar Nicholas II was crowned, she outlived the Soviet Union by a generation, according to her internal Russian passport. Her date of birth was claimed to be  June  - when Queen Victoria was on the throne in Britain. But her passport gave only a year of her birth, not the exact day and month.   In extraordinary and moving testimony broadcast last year she spoke emotionally of the appalling day her native Chechen people were deported en masse by Stalin to the steppes of Kazakhstan  years ago. She told how people died in the cattle-truck trains - and their bodies were thrown out of the carriages to be eaten by hungry dogs. If her age was correct, Koku was  at the time, having earlier lived through the coronation of the last tsar Nicholas II two days before her th birthday - and his toppling when she was . “It was a bad day, cold and gloomy,” she said of the February morning in  when the entire entire nation was banished from their mountain homeland in the Trans-Causacus. “We were put in a train and taken … no one knew where. “Railway carriages were stuffed with people - dirt, rubbish, excrement was everywhere.” Stressing the cruelty of Stalin’s action, she told journalists determinedly in her native Chechen language: “Write that - there was excrement in the carriages.   “We were not allowed [to go] anywhere.” Young Caucasus girls died because from the rupturing of their bladders - they were ashamed to go to the toilet in crowded stinking the crowded trains. Older women tried to crowd round them to stop their embarrassment as they relieved themselves. Yet there was worse. “On the way to our exile, dead bodies were just thrown out of the train,” she said. “Nobody was allowed to bury the dead. “Corpses were eaten by dogs. My father-in-law was thrown out of the train in this way.” A paranoid Stalin had alleged the Chechens were collaborating with the Nazis. “We were told that we were bad people and thats why we had to leave,” she said. Before the war, she recalled “scary” Nazi tanks passing her family home. She suffered devastating personal bereavements in her Kazakh hell - her two sons both perished in the harsh conditions. “There were no doctors, no-one to treat them,” she said. “My younger boy came down with something and passed away really quickly.   Such things happened in every family. “When women gave birth children often died because there were no obstetricians, only neighbours and friends.” Weeping the old lady said: “I only kept my daughter Tamara.” She was exiled in Kazakhstan for  years then, after Stalin’s death, people were allowed toto their homeland. When she got back, many houses had been grabbed by incoming Russians - so she set to work building her own home, complaining her husband was too lazy for the work. She conceded that despite her earlier claim, the day she moved into her own house, built with her own hands, after ing from internal Soviet exile was “happy”. “I built it myself, the best house in the world,” she said. “I lived there for  years.” Asked about the secret of going le, she previously said: “It was God’s will. “I did nothing to make it happen. “I see people going in for sports, eating something special, keeping themselves fit, but I have no idea how I lived until now.” Her recipe for a long le was fermented milk, but she shunned meat and soup. She asked: Why did Allah give me such a long le and so little happiness .... “I would have been dead long ago,not for Allah who was holding me in his arms.” Koku said: “It is hard to live when all who remembered you died long ago. And it is very scary to die, however old you are.” The oldest documented human was Jeanne Calment, from France, who lived  years,  days, dying in . French scientists have dismissed a recent claim from Russian researchers who argued she assumed the identity of her dead daughter and was not as old as records show.

story: A £ million plan to transform Perth City Hall has been approved, triggering a jobs boost.Council bosses have secured planning consent to convert the historic venue into the Fair City’s equivalent of the VA, expected to attract more than , visitors each year.A study has revealed the ambitious project could create work for nearly  people, while pumping about £m into the economy.Council boss Murray Lyle said it was “now full-steam ahead” for the project.He said: “The former city hall is a landmark in the heart of Perth.“Combined with the ongoing work to transform St Paul’s Church and the recently unveiled plans to create a new public space at Guard Vennel, we’re sending a clear message to businesses, visitors and residents that we are committed to investing in Perth city centre as a place to enjoy food, music, art and heritage.”The work will involve a major overhaul of the former hall and two large gateways – decorated with curved, bronze-coloured metal – which are built on the north and south sides of the building.The original entrance doors, on the west side, will be replaced with huge windows offering views of the exhibition area, and a -cover cafe will be created in the lesser hall.

title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”

title: dundee united sign former st johnstone defender mark connolly
story: Dundee United have signed defender Mark Connolly from Crawley Town for an undisclosed fee.Irish-born Connolly joins United on a contract until the end of season .As a youngster, he spent a season at St Johnstone and two seasons at Kilmarnock where he became club captain between two separate periods at Crawley Town.He has represented Ireland at Under , Under  and  level.The -year-old becomes Robbie Neilson#s ninth signing of the January window and third of a busy final day. He brings great experience and an excellent attitude to the dressing room and pitch.#I am delighted to make him a Dundee United player.”

title: dundee uniteds nicky clark says we are making life very hard for ourselves
story: Nicky Clark admits Dundee United are “making it very hard for ourselves” as their bid for promotion to the Premiership stumbles yet again.The Tangerines fell six points behind leaders Ross County and three behind Ayr United after losing to the Honest Men - last Friday.With  matches remaining in the Championship race, Clark admits the Tangerines need to pick up three points more often than not between now and the end of the campaign.And that starts this weekend at home to Greenock Morton.The striker said: “We’re still up there, still round about it but we know we need to pick up now.“The next game is massive for us now, we need three points because we are making it really hard for ourselves but we need to just concentrate on our own matches and it’s important we pick up three points from most games between now and the end of the season.“There is still plenty of time, especially in this league because everybody seems to beat everybody, but it’s games like Friday you need to go and winyou want to win titles.“Friday we didn’t manage that so we only have ourselves to blame.“However, we have Morton this weekend and we can galvanise ourselves and get three points.“Saturday will be tough – it’s all good teams in this league so we need to prepare ourselves this week. The gaffer will get us ready for it and we need to make sure we go and do the business.”The performance at Somerset Park was a bitter disappointment for the  United fans who made the long trip on a Friday night.And Clark admits it wasn’t good enough from the Tangerines.He added: “We went down to Ayr with full intentions of winning the game.“We gave ourselves a chance a couple of weeks ago against Dunfermline when we won and got ourselves up the league but we let ourselves and the fans down on Friday.“The weather meant it was never going to be a pretty game and they got a chance early on and took it.“I think we only had one real chance with Aidan towards the end where the goalie was out quick and made a good save.“All in all it was a very frustrating night and we were very disappointed.”Strong winds made le dficult for all the players but it was clear Ian McCall’s men coped far better with the conditions than United.The home side dominated the opening period and got their goal through Craig Moore early on but the expected response from the Tangerines with the wind in their favour in the second half never really materialised.Clark added: “It was dficult conditions but we’ve all played in wind like that before, we all know what it’s like.“We had a game plan – I don’t knowwe didn’t stick to it but it never happened for us.“We’re disappointed because that’s nine points we’ve given Ayr this season and we’re making it very hard for ourselves.”It’s been a stop-start first season at the club for Clark with a series of injuries curtailing his first-team opportunities.Now, though, he says he’s back to % and ready to help United get back on track.“It’s been very frustrating for me, I’ve missed a lot of games with daft wee injuries here and there where you can’t actually treat them, you just have to leave them until they get better.“It’s been frustrating but I’m back and feeling good now so, hopefully, I can kick on now and help the team get where we want to be.”

title: end of an era as historic dundee skatepark set to close
story: A Dundee skatepark – the UK’s first purpose-built indoor extreme sports arena – will close next week. vw, px"  The Factory Skatepark in Douglas will shut on February  before being converted into a £, family entertainment centre, complete with soft play and adult obstacle course.Mark Selvey, The Factory’s deputy chief executive, said the move was due to a declining interest in skating.He said: “We are sad and this is going be disappointing news for hardcore fans, but there aren’t enough of them.“There has been a clear decline in wheeled sports over the years andit wasn’t for scooters, the decline would be much worse.“We are going to revamp into a family entertainment centre with ninja warriors for adults and a soft play area.”He added: “We are going to fill up , feet worth of space for the new entertainment centre so it’s going to be big.”Mark also confirmed plans to lease out the neighbouring building – which hosts the Fun Factory soft play centre – and move elements of the soft play facility into the existing skatepark arena.The Factory took over the premises in , after The Gate church had first invested £, into a skateboarding facility in .Mark added: “The sport has changed massively. But one of our main aims has always been to develop it and concentrate on youth work by making a dference to people’s lives through the sport.“One of our users moved away to Australia to became an inline skater and he mentions how his le wouldn’t be the sameit wasn’t for the skatepark.“It is definitely a huge part of Dundee’s heritage.“But the current model of how the skatepark is run has become unsustainable.”He said work on the new centre will begin the day after closure and it will reopen on March .

title: former dundee united man one of two new arrivals at dundee

story: Dundee United midfielder Fraser Aird has joined fellow Championship side Queen of the South.Aird was a key player for United earlier in the season, contributing three goals and  assists in  games, but has fallen out of favour since Robbie Neilson took the reins.The -year-old Canadian has gone to Dumfries on loan until the end of the season.Queen of the South boss Gary Naysmith said: “I am delighted and also a little surprised that we have managed to bring Fraser to the club.#With Dundee United changing their manager recently and Robbie wanting to bring in his own players, Fraser has found himself on the outside looking in in recent weeks and once we thought we had a chance of getting him we moved quickly to add him to the squad.#He is only  and is a current Canadian international, who was in outstanding form for Dundee United earlier in the season.#He has three goals and twelve assists from  games this season and is someone who will add another dimension to our attacking threat.#Fraser is comfortable playing on either wing, he has a lot of experience for someone his age having played over  games for Rangers, Vancouver, Dunfermline, Falkirk and Dundee United as well as having eight caps for Canada.#

title: reveald dundee council may invite bids for exclusive slessor gardens music rights
story: Dundee City Council is considering inviting bids for the exclusive live music rights for Slessor Gardens, the Tele can reveal.Last week we reported that the local authority had held talks about handing rights for the space to the Liz Hobbs Group , the company behind most of the Waterfront’s big name gigs.But according to emails seen by the Tele, it now appears the council will put the deal out to tender in a “transparent” process to get “the best outcome for the city”.The council has also stopped seeking gigs for  or , as it reviews “all intended and possible works taking place at the ious commercial sites surrounding Slessor Gardens, and the implications for the use of Slessor Gardens during ”.A number of promoters have complained about being “ignored” by the council when they asked to hold live music events at Slessor Gardens.Two local companies – LCC Live and Events  – are considering legal action after being “stonewalled” by the council on the subject of potential Slessor shows.Les Kidger, director of LCC Live – which is bringing Jess Glynne and Madness to Montrose and Noel Gallagher’s High Flying Birds to Inverness – said the situation was “totally wrong”.He added: “Dundee City Council just won’t talk to us. It should leave the site open for all promoters. We’re at the stage where we are looking at the legal route.”Last week, Events  told the Tele it had been on the verge of bringing a “multi-platinum band” to the city but had to put the plan on ice after the council refused to provide dates.Ronnie Smith, a director of the company – responsible for bringing Paul Gascoigne and John Lydon to Dundee – said: “This isn’t about just us putting on shows.“The idea that irrespective of who we bring to the table, it’s a ‘no’ before discussions start will put promoters off.”Geoff Ellis, boss of T In The Park and TRNSMT organisers DF Concerts, has previously spoken about his frustration in attempting to secure shows at the Waterfront.He has previously vowed to seek gigs for  – but did not respond to a request for comment on the council’s latest move.LHG has so far announced two Slessor Gardens gigs this year – Craig David on June  and Sir Tom Jones on July  – with a third act due to be revealed later.The council has repeatedly denied it is seeking an exclusivity deal with a single promoter.In the council’s only official statement on the matter, city development convener Lynne Short said: “There is no exclusivity agreement in place for Slessor Gardens with any promoters.“The council is carefully considering the future of the space as a venue.”

title: womans horror after doctor says her medical records sent to random dundee address
story: A woman in has spoken of her relief after her sensitive medical history was recovered, having originally believed it had been sent to a “random” house in error.Lisa Rooney, from Forfar, was informed by a doctor at the Whitehill Health Centre her records had been sent to an address in Dundee.A Tele investigation has now discovered the document never reached the unknown address.The -year-old visited the surgery about an operation earlier last week.She said the appointment was about a procedure to be carried out at either Perth Royal Infirmary or Ninewells Hospital.But she was told by a doctor the letter and a number of recent scans had been sent to an address in Dundee.Amid the confusion, Lisa spent days worrying her confidential medical data had been shared when it should not have been.Lisa said: “I was absolutely devastated.“I could understandsomeone by the same name as me living in the same street was sent the letter in error.“It’s an entirely dferent place, miles away from my home.”“I was given a verbal apology from the doctor.“This could have been a major breach of sensitive data.“I just don’t understand how they got it so wrong.“I’ve lived at my address for almost three years, so it’s not asI’ve moved in recently.“The doctor asked meI knew the person to whom the letter was addressed.“It’s horrying to think this may have landed on someone ’s doorstep.“They could have opened the letter without fully registering who it was for.“The content of the letter has information that only my closest family are aware of.“It’s a relief to know now that it wasn’t sent.A spokesman for NHS Tayside said: “Due to patient confidentiality, we are unable to comment on matters relating to inidual patients.“NHS Tayside takes the security of information very seriously and would encourage the patient to contact us by emailing the information governance team at informationgovernance.tayside@nhs.net, or by telephone on  .”

story: Celtic have been dealt another injury blow with Tom Rogic ruled out of this months Europa League tie against Valencia. "When he ed we had a plan for him to go to London for a scan just to make sure his hand didnrsquot need an operation. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Clachnacuddin FC pays tribute to superfan from Yorkshire
story: Bronwyn Wain , who lived in Huddersfield, was described as a ldquolovely lady and ldquoreal character by club figures.Despite living in Yorkshire, her unlikely association with the club began in  when she got in touch with the Lilywhites out of curiosity about the clubrsquos name and history.The links grew from there and she became a true Lily when she visited Grant Street as club guest in . Her husband John, who passed away a few months ago, joined her.ldquoThey were a lovely couple. Just ordinary folk who took the club to their hearts and they became well-known to many of our players, directors and fans, said Billy Corbett, a former director of the club. ldquoIt was the name Clachnacuddin that attracted her attention. Its a Gaelic word and means lsquothe stone of the tubrsquo. But when she got in touch we responded by sending her a hat and scarf and some programmes.ldquoShe was absolutely thrilled and kept in touch through Facebook checking results and encouraging the team. She sent money every month to one of our fans to buy her ticket in the Lily Lotto. She had so many friends the club had a whip round for her and her husband to visit.During the trip they attended a Clach game against Strathspey Thistle , which the Lilywhites won - ndash a result which left the couple ldquotickled pink. Former director Jim Oliver also showed them round town and on a cruise down Loch Ness.ldquoI donrsquot think they had ever been to Scotland but they got a real taste of Highland League hospitality, Mr Corbett added.Following her death the couplersquos son Michael passed on his heartfelt thanks to Clach fans and officials for all they had done for his parents.Jim Oliver said: ldquoA lovely lady whom the Clach Facebook followers got to know very well. All in all she was a real character.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: DJ marathon charity event in Inverness aims to be a money spinner
story: Several local DJs will take to the decks during the Caledonian V Cancer event this Saturday in aid of CLIC Sargent.The music starts at pm and finishes at am on Sunday, and the sound selectors will include DJs Terry Fire, Lady Beats, Andy Innis, CKaz and Richard Lewis.The event has been organised in memory of Michael Murphy who succumbed to cancer last year aged .Michaelrsquos uncle Sean , of Dalneigh, is a regular in the bar.Sean has already organised several fundraising events across Inverness, and so far he has raised more than pound for the charity.Sean said he was really grateful to the Caledonian and all the DJs for their support, adding: ldquoMichael first became unwell in  and he had two forms of leukaemia and sadly died last September.ldquoCLIC Sargent really helped us through some hard times so I became involved in the fundraising.Michael was involved in last yearrsquos Stand Up To Cancer campaign on Channel  having been filmed for the national fundraiser prior to his death.The former factory worker and McDonaldrsquos crew member lived in Forres before moving to Inverness.Mark Glendinning, general manager of the Caledonian, said: ldquoWe try to support as many local events as possible, but this one is particularly special as Sean is both a friend and regular customer.ldquoCLIC Sargent is a wonderful charity that supports cancer patients and their families during incredibly dficult times.ldquoThey were particularly helpful to Michaelrsquos we Shannon and young daughter Sophia after he passed away, so we want to help Sean raise funds for them to give something back.CLIC Sargent supports children and young people with cancer and leukaemia and the Caledonian event will be held ahead of World Cancer Day on Monday.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Game group boosts Highland Hospice coffers
story: Sixteen members and guests of the Borlum game shooting syndicate, Scaniport, managed to more than double a total raised last year, with local businesses also helping with donations in kind.The group staged a three-course bothy lunch, an extensive auction of donated goods and a series of competitions including th century musketry, a clay pigeon shoot and retriever dummy-throwing.More than  auction items donated by members and guests ranged from home-made honey and tablet to malt whiskies, artworks and several hundred kilos of firewood.Local businesses added support, including outdoor specialists Grahams, which chipped in two daysrsquo trout fishing, Highland Industrial Supplies and Allans of Gillock with tools and workwear, Harbro with a retail voucher, Tesco with food and Scissor Sisters of Dingwall with haircut vouchers. Scaniport Estate made a direct donation of pound, to bring the total raised to pound.Borlum farmer Alan Fraser, who was auctioneer for the day and whose we Yvonne and others produced the meal, said: ldquoIt was a great effort by all, an enjoyable afternoon and a huge thousand-pound increase on the pound raised last year. We all appreciate what a tremendous personal service the Highland Hospice provides for our community, and that it costs about pound a day to run, so every small event and contribution helps.Highland Hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb added: ldquoI would like to say a huge thank you to everyone who organised and participated, as well as the businesses who supported it. To raise nearly pound is just fantastic and will be appreciated by those who rely on our care.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted over strike action
story: The Prospect Union has already notied Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdthat it will be asking air traffic controllers to cast a vote regarding a strike. An indicative ballot in October gained overwhelming support.The dispute centres on the controllers at Inverness and where being paid much less than their counterparts further south, which the union maintains is unfair.An innovative centralised air traffic control system that many fear could lead to job losses in years to come has also added to the bitterness in the dispute, though it is not part of the current move.Before Christmas both Prospect and HIAL agreed to an evidence-based business case that set out the pay gap between HIAL and the rest of the industry in an attempt to resolve the dispute.Prospect believesHIAL cannot attract and retain controllers through pay issues, this has and will continue to cause staff shortages and pose a risk to maintaining service provision.According to the union it has no choice but to move towards industrial action after Scottish Ministers rejected the business case earlier this week without explanation and with no additional funding offered.Prospect negotiation officer David Avery said: ldquoScottish Ministers have been promising pay restoration for public sector workers but their policy fails to deliver.ldquoThere is a global shortage of air traffic controllers which is driving wages up across the industry - at the same time HIAL staff have received below inflation pay awards.ldquoIt is unfair that a HIAL air traffic controller, providing an essential service for the Highlands and Islands, is being paid half as much their counterpart in London ndash enough is enough.ldquoOur members have tried every other means to resolve this dispute but by rejecting a fair and reasonable proposal to resolve the dispute ministers have left them with no option but to pursue strike action.HIAL HR director Andrea Sillars, said: ldquoHIAL note the position taken by the Ministers. We are disappointed that Prospect have decided to ballot their members on strike action. We remain committed to continuing constructive discussions to help resolve the dispute and are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for Air Traffic Control staff. We await the outcome of the ballot.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland Council vows to continue dialogue after 3300 SNAP petition submitted
story: Worried parents handed in a -signature online petition to the council today in an effort to save Special Needs Action Project .Later following a meeting between council chief executive Donna Manson, council officers and Snap manager Dawn Walker and Snap board chairman Donald Robertson, the council issued a statement saying it recognises ldquothe very much valued support this organisation provides to families in Inverness.Ms Manson said: ldquoOfficers are continuing dialogue with Snap to identy other possible sources of funding to help achieve a viable position. We will be entering into early discussions with Snap and other third sector organisations regarding need, service requirements and formal processes to allocate funding. There will be a workshop in February with members of the third sector, including SNAP, to agree methods of funding and how we can redesign our processes.She added: ldquoOur discussions have been useful and I have given a clear commitment from the council that we will work with the third sector to help lever funding from where as we work together for the benefit of all Highland communities.Ms Walker said: ldquoWhile the meeting was more positive, we are still in a position of not knowing what is going to happen.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: One man campaign to safeguard cyclists
story: Allie Middletonfrom Balnakyle Road is concerned about the visibility of a cycle path which cuts through trees and merges with the east junction with Lochy Road and he is urging locals to campaign for improved awareness and traffic calming measures.ldquoI just happen to live opposite the cycle track. I would never be able to forgive myselfsomething happened and I hadnrsquot done something about it, said Mr Middleton.He is particularly concerned that many drivers do not know the cycle track is there because it is set back roughly  metres from the road, through the garden of the Green Drive Hall.Mr Middleton said when the cycle path was upgraded three years ago, a barrier was removed which had separated the path clearly from the road.There is now a sign at the end of the path before it meets the road, warning cyclists to dismount. But Mr Middleton said that the sign was being ignored and there was a danger at the bend where cyclists meet traffic.Speed reducing tables have been installed at the site, but Mr Middleton said: ldquoCars are going over the raised tables at mph and then drivers are putting the foot down in between them.He has reported his concerns to the council who carried out a survey in May last year. It revealed the average speed in the mph zone at the busiest time in the morning is .mph.He is now urging the council to instal signs to alert the drivers to the oncoming cyclists or a speed indicating devicewhich will show road users their speed.The path is used by pupils from Lochardil Primary, Inverness Royal Academy Holm Primary and the Gaelic school.Mr Middleton fears young people on the path may not be seen by fast moving vehicles: ldquoWe have crossed this road many times andin the company of two or four of my grandchildren this is more dficult, the main reason for this is in estimating the speed of accelerating vehicles since the tables were installed said Mr Middleton.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoA mph zone was recently installed in the Culduthel Lochardil area at the request of the community council. The scheme which encompasses Balnakyle Road includes appropriate signage and associated traffic calming features. Highland Council are monitoring speeds and will be making the police awarea persistent speeding problem is demonstrated. The concerns... will be investigated.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: charlie house serves up fizz and fun raising
story: A first-of-its-kind brunch event is to be held at an Aberdeen five-star hotel.Charlie House, a children’s charity which supports babies, children and young people with complex disabilities and le-limiting conditions, is to host foodie fun to help raise funds for its Big Build Appeal.The Big Brunch is supporting the £ million fundraising campaign to build a specialist support centre in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.The event, at the Marclfe Hotel and Spa, will feature food, fizz and a range of games and entertainment.There will also be a raffle, along with local DJ Kev Reid spinning Motown and soul hits.Rhona Miller, fundraising team manager at Charlie House, said: “We’re delighted to add the Big Brunch to our fundraising calendar. It’s the first charity event of its kind in the city and offers guests a decadent brunch, fizz and fun – all for a very important local cause.”The Big Build Appeal launched in November, with more than £.m already raised.The support centre will be the first of its kind in the north-east and will provide facilities and respite care to children.Currently families have to travel more than  miles, to Kinross, to access support services.Featuring eight bedrooms and family accommodation, the new centre will be staffed by specially trained professionals and facilities will include a sensory room, library, spa pool, craft room, teen den, soft play area and therapy room, alongside a star room for end-of-le care and bereavement.It will be a place where families can spend precious time with their child after they have passed away.It has been a dream of Charlie House’s to create the site since the charity was founded in  by chairwoman Tracy Johnstone.In the north-east, there are more than , babies, children and young people living with complex disabilities and le-limiting conditions.Charlie House already offers activity clubs, siblings clubs, a community nurse, one-to-one emotional and practical support and an annual fun trip to Kielder Forest Park in Northumberland, but the new centre will allow them to support families more.The Big Brunch will take place on February  from am until pm. Limited tickets for the event are still available.They cost £ per person and include a drink on arrival.For more information, or to buy a ticket, contact   or email fundraise@ charliehouse. org.uk

title: mummy to go on display in us tour
story: An Aberdeen university’s ancient Egyptian mummy is to go on display in the US.Ta-Kheru, born around BC, has been in Aberdeen University’s collections for more than  years, but underwent D facial reconstruction technology last year.She was previously part of an exhibition at Sir Duncan Rice Library Gallery, which closed on December .The lid of her coffin was with a number of other items from the university’s Egypt collection, which was on display in Victoria, British Columbia.Ta-Kheru will now join her coffin for a tour of the US this month, beginning in Cincinnati, in a partnership with Germany’s Roemer and Pelizaeus Museum of Hidesheim.Neil Curtis, head of museums and special collections at Aberdeen University, said: “The university’s museum collections are renowned worldwide, and this exhibition continues to enhance our reputation for making remarkable items accessible to the public.”

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: brave mcdonalds worker hailed hero
story: NewsBrave McDonalds worker hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from fireLewis Macdonald, , battled back flames and thick smoke to save the le of Nan MarshallShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLewis saved the le of Nan Marshall. "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave McDonald’s worker has been hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from a burning home. Lewis Macdonald, , battled flames and thick smoke to save the le of granny-of-three Nan Marshall from a blaze which broke out in her living room. The sht manager was driving past -year-old Nan’s home on Castlehill Road in the early hours of New Year’s Eve when he saw flames flickering in the window. A Las Vegas neon sign – which Nan popped on for the festivities – had caught alight. Quick-thinking Lewis, along with pal Lauren Kennedy, sounded the alarm, got Nan to safety and dampened the fire with towels before the fire brigade arrived at the scene.Lewis told the Ayrshire Post : “The whole night was a blur.“We were driving back from work and I saw a fire in the window. “I was chapping on the door and ringing the doorbell. “The full house was covered in black smoke. “I couldn’t see anything. “I didn’t know how long the firemen were going to take and the house was still on fire so I thought I needed to do something. “Nan was shook up about it. “I was trying to get into the kitchen because Nan said there were towels at the washing machine. “They were pretty damp so I just threw them over it. “After we put the fire out, we sat on the wall and waited for thefiremen. They had a big extractor fan and they were trying to get all the smoke out.“It had even got upstairs, the firefighters said.” Nan was upstairs sleeping at the time unaware as to what was going on. She said: “I wondered what it was. “I could hear the doorbell and by this time the smoke alarm kicked in. “Luckily I woke and came down the stairs and there was my hero at the door. “Buthe hadn’t of been here I would’ve been a goner with the smoke alone. “Even now, anything you touch you’re covered in black soot. “I was in a state of shock. “The table caught fire and the windowsill. “I had to go to the doctor two or three days later because I kept wheezing.” Daughter Lesley Watson, , added: “It could’ve been so much worse –Lewis just caught it in time. “If that young man hadn’t been passing, she wouldn’t be here today.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. story: NewsWoman wielded air rle and metal pole during rammy at Ayrshire houseThe -year-old admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAyr Sherf Court "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA weapon wielding woman terried homeowners as she smashed windows during a violent air rle spree. Danielle Smith, , used a metal pole to shatter windows of a home on Ness Glen Road, Dalmellington on November , . But she didn’t act alone as Smith was spotted alongside a male when the pair terried their targets inside. Ayr Sherf Court heard he appeared to be carrying a black air rle. But Smith, of Castle Croft, Dalmellington, admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home. And the victims inside cowered in fear as they could hear Smith shouting “Get out here, get our here.” CCTV footage captured the pair on their threatening violent spree. Almost every window in the home had been smashed and holes in the windows were consistent with shots of the rle. Blood smears were spotted on the living room window. Police were called and discovered the metal pole used by Smith the following morning. A search warrant in Smith’s home uncovered pellets for an air rle in a box within her bedroom. But she told officers that the other person had been carrying the gun and she had never seen the gun before. She also stated that she threw the metal pole away as she believed the other person would have used it. Solicitor Steven Maxwell told the court he had viewed the footage. The lawyer commented: “It’s quite clear that she was quite literally in his stead and following him. “She cannot provide the court any reasonable explanation of how she managed to get herself in this situation but she was using and abusing drink and illegal substances. “At the time she would have followed this man where-ever he went. “If you fly with the crows, you get shot with them. Mr Maxwell said that Smith has “managed to turn her le around”. He added: “The young woman who appears before you is a very dferent woman. “She understands the seriousness of this.” Sherf Scott Pattison told Smith: “My first thought was to send you to jail for this shameful behaviour and very serious nature. “However I’m going to draw back from that because of your current progress in the community payback order. “I’m told by the social work department that you’re doing well. “You’re currently free from substance and alcohol misuse which is the big thing. “Butyou transgress, you’ll go straight to jail and it’ll be for a signicant period.” Smith admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner and, whilst acting with another, shouted, did kick and strike the door with a metal pole, point the barrel of an air rle into the home and smash windows.
