story: LIBRARY users in the Borders can now reserve and renew items, check opening times and more through an easy-to-use app.Via the lsquoIguanarsquo app, library members in the region can search and reserve items, cancel reservations, renew items on loan, view payments due, and even create a lsquowish listrsquo of books they would like to read.Cameron McAulay, digital and media officer service officer at Live Borders, said: If yoursquore out and about and find yourself in a bookshop, you can scan a bookrsquos ISBN barcode and check whether your library has a copy."As I always say, lsquoWhy buy when you can borrow rsquoFrom mobile phones, tablets and computers, you can send emails to your local branch from the app.And,you use the app via your mobile phone, you can make phone calls to a branch with one click.The Iguana app is a useful addition to Live Borders library services and along with the apps for eAudiobook, eBooks, eMagazines and eComics.Cameron added: ldquoWersquore constantly striving to offer the best possible access to our libraries, both in terms of physical spaces, and our virtual library s."And, wersquore hoping the app will encourage more busy people to use their local library"One of the barriers to using libraries is the fear of being fined for having overdue books. With the app, users receive push notications for loans nearing their expiry date."And, as you can renew resources via the app, you should never need to worry about an overdue fee again."To access all the features, download the lsquoIguanarsquo app on your device and enter your pin to get started.The app also links to Google Maps, which meanssomeone does not know where their local library is or how to get there, they can look up directions via the app.

title: unemployed-young-borderers-offered-a-sporting-chance-by-live-borders
story: UP to  unemployed Borders are to be given a sporting chance in the job market.A successful funding bid to the Year of Young People National Lottery Fund has allowed local charity, Live Borders to launch a new employability programme.LIVE My Future is a -week scheme for young people aged between  and  who live in the region and are currently unemployed and who are not in education or training.The aim of LIVE My Future is to boost their employment by providing each candidate with work experience within the sport, leisure and cultural industry whilst also upskilling them with industry specic qualications.Project lead Ewan Lindores told us: ldquoLIVE My Future is the first employability programme of its kind in the Scottish Borders that will bring together sport, leisure and culture."Candidates will have the opportunity to gain invaluable work experience whilst also gaining qualications and boosting their overall confidence."The goal is that we see each candidate either progress into paid employment with Live Borders or another local employer, or gain access to further education.ldquoItrsquos all part of Live Borders strategy to develop a place where young people are healthier, happier and stronger.The first four weeks of training will involve candidates completing a Level  sports leadership course in and around Galashiels.During weeks five and six, candidates will be involved in supporting Live Borders Easter holiday programmes and attending relevant training and development courses.The remaining ten weeks will involve each candidate attending a Live Bordersrsquo work placement that relates to one of the four LIVE My Future pathways on offer ndash Coaching, Operations, Events and Hospitality, and Creative and Connected Communities.The coaching pathway will incorporate work with Active Schools, Sports Development, Play and Health Intervention Promotion. The Operations pathway will involve candidates working within a Live Bordersrsquo facility, supporting the day-to-day running of the facility while also gaining experience of how it is managed.The Events and Hospitality pathway will involve a mix of work with Live Bordersrsquo Events and Programming Officer, helping to plan and deliver small to large-scale events in and around the Scottish Borders, as well as hospitality work within venues such as Heart of Hawick, Harestanes and the Teviotdale Leisure Centre Cafeacute.And the Creative and Connected Communities pathway will involve work within a Live Bordersrsquo archive, library or museum, supporting the day-to-day running and gaining experience of how it is managed.LIVE My Future starts on Monday, March and will run until Friday, June .For the duration of the programme, each candidate will receive pound per week plus travel expenses.Iniduals who are interested in applying must send their CV and submit an application form in writing to Emily Ho, Direct Partners,  Rutland Square, Edinburgh, EH BB or by email to emily@directpartnersApplication forms can be downloaded via the website, www.liveborders.org.uk livemyfuture.The deadline for applications is pm on Friday, February .

title: jazz-comes-to-fountainhall
story: JAZZ festival favourites Ian Millar and Dominic Spencer are heading to Fountainhall next month.Ian and Dominic have been performing together for a number of years playing melodic improvisations on jazz standards and original compositions.Their style of jazz concentrates on developing melodic ideas within the framework of the melody of a tune, whilst maintaining the concept and groove behind it.The result is a very accessible melodic style which allows them to explore, improvise and develop ideas without losing the essence of each piece of music, and to interact together in as creative a way as possible.They have had enormous success over many years during the Edinburgh Fringe Festival with their very successful show ldquoJazz at Lunchtime.Thousands of people have come to see them perform, with many sell-out shows. Anumber of visitors to the Edinburgh Fringe from all over the world have ed year after year.Based in Edinburgh, Scotland, the duo has regularly and extensively toured throughout the UK.They have embarked on many rural tours under their ldquoJazz in the Village series, playing in hundreds of halls, often bringing jazz for the first time to remote communities, performing in intimate settings to appreciative audiences.And the good people of Fountainhall will be able to hear why they are so popular when Ian and Domic pull up at the village hall on Friday, February .Tickets, priced at pound for adults and free for accompanies children, are available from Stow Post Office,

title: gods-kitchen-is-serving-up-a-community-feast-in-selkirk
story: THEY may not be feeding , quite yet but Gods Kitchen in Selkirk is certainly pulling in the punters.Founded last September by Selkirk Baptist Church the Sunday afternoon dining club is proving to be hugely popular.Dozens enjoy the weekly feast and blether, aptly named Gods Kitchen.And even more will be made welcome.Rev Brian Talbot told us: "Its a new kind of church service every Sunday afternoon for folk that have some faith or none."The service consists in sharing a first class home-cooked meal around a table with folk who might find church a little daunting."Between the main course and desert, someone might share some creative writing, someone might bring a guitar and share a song, one of the children might show us a picture theyrsquove just coloured in."We read from the bible."Jesus had a lot to say whilst sharing a meal with ordinary folk in the community."Sometimes what Jesus said, leads us into a good conversation - other times, we go straight for the pudding."Sukie, from Sukiersquos Scones pop-up shop fame, is the main Gods Kitchen chef.And theres rarely a scrap left on the plates by the end of each meal.Selkirk Baptist Church provides the meals for free and theyd like to share their generosity far and wide.The Rev Talbot added: "The outcome is community."We are meeting neighbours of all ages, from all walks of le, becoming friends and sharing burdens in prayer."Itrsquos been goodhellipand we want more folk to come join us."Gods Kitchen takes place every Sunday afternoon from .pm at Connections,  Back Row, Selkirk.

title: parent-power-raises-langlee-classroom-from-the-ashes
story: TEACHERS at a Galashiels primary school has hailed the parent power which has led to a torched outdoor classroom being rebuilt.Pupils, teachers and parents at Langlee Primary were devastated last November when they discovered a woodland hut and surrounding fence had been set alight by vandals.The woodland area adjoining the school was popular with children from pre-school age all the way up to primary seven for outdoor activities.Due to the damage, the whole area had to be cordoned off by staff.And police were brought in to investigate the crime.During December mum Nicola Kelly dipped into her own pocket to buy timber and as she recruited fellow parent Chris Brown to help to raise the outdoor classroom from the ashes.And earlier this month the new hut was officially opened.Langlee teacher Keith Guthrie told us: "The space is a valuable learning resource for the pupils who were very upset when they discovered what had happened and could not access it."Chris did a wonderful job in cold weather and spoke to very inquisitive children about what he was doing."We as a school would like to thank Nicola for organising and paying for all of this and it came as a complete surprise when we found out it was going ahead."We are proud to have such positive people as part of our school community and are delighted they thought of us when it came to this act of kindness and generosity."As well as purchasing most of the materials for the new hut, mum Nicola recruited local joiner Chris to carry out the building work.Mr Brown, who has children at Langlee Primary, volunteered his services and for two days removed the damaged sections before building the new outdoor classroom.Chris told us: "I love working with wood and it has been a pleasure to work on the hut."I enjoyed speaking to the kids and letting them know about how to fix things and how to be safe when using the dferent tools."Local firm Jewsons donated products to treat the finished wood.Mum Nicola is delighted with the new outdoor classroom.She said: "All of my children have used this space from nursery age and have loved using this space to explore the woodland area."Itrsquos a great benefit to the whole school and I just wanted to do something nice."

title: jobseeker-remanded-after-disturbance-at-benefits-office
story: A BORDERS jobseeker has been found guilty after a trial at Jedburgh Sherf Court of causing a disturbance in an unemployment benefit office.Forty five year old Noel Kelly, of Deanhead Drive in Eyemouth, had denied behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in the premises at Upper Houndlaw in Eyemouth on Wednesday, December .After finding him guilty of shouting and swearing and threatening staff, Sherf Derrick McIntytre deferred sentence until February  for the production of background reports.Kelly was remanded in custody until that date.

title: scottish-borders-council-to-be-asked-to-back-second-brexit-vote
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is being asked to back a second vote on Brexit.Opposition leader Stuart Bellhas submitted a motion which would see the council writing to both Holyrood and Westminster in support of either a second referendum or a general election.The motion reads: ldquoAs the UK Parliament has been unable to agree upon terms for withdrawal from the EU and as the facts about, and implications of, withdrawal are now clear, Scottish Borders Council considers that the case for withdrawal should be directly decided by the British people on the basis of the actual facts.ldquoThe council resolves to communicate this opinion to the UK Government and to all local MPs and MSPs.Outlining his reasons for submitting the motion, councillor Bell commented: ldquoThe potential impact on the Borders economy of a chaotic departure from the European Union could be so severe that I think the council cannot sit back and not express an opinion. ldquoI tried to get Scottish Borders Council to wake up to Brexit challenges in March last year, but a motion proposed then was defeated by five votes with those refusing to take action, or refusing even to have an opinion, arguing that it was premature. ldquoI donrsquot think that argument will carry weight now, with just two months to go before we leave Europe. The council needs to take a lead and speak up.ldquoIt is now clear, and indeed it is alarming, that the UK Parliament is blocked and has been unable to make a clear decision on which route to take and on how Brexit should be brought to pass.ldquoThe clock is ticking down to a departure from Europe and just last week the confederation of British industry stated that under some scenarios there could be lsquodisastrousrsquo implications for Scottish productivity and economic prospects. ldquoWhilst that is only some scenarios, it is unacceptable to me that the UK Parliament cannot decide what to do. ldquoThe decision should be put back to the people, precisely because Parliament is now blocked. That could be through a general election or it could be through another EU referendum.ldquoI maintain that to now have a referendum, based on definite proposals and on an honest statement of the facts about leaving Europe would not betray the decision taken in . ldquoThe real options were not clear two years ago, but now we have some facts. Anyway, people who are confident of their arguments donrsquot run away from a referendum.ldquoBut maybe the people should decide through a general election. Either way the UK Parliament is failing on this and now the people, themselves, must decide.The council meets on Thursday, January , where elected members will be asked to vote on councillor Bellrsquos motion.

title: council-could-help-with-food-crackdown
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council officers could take on a larger role policing the selling and marketing of high fat, high sugar and high salt foods.In a paper which is set to go before councillors on Thursday, council officers have outlined a draft response to a Scottish Government consultation on reducing health problems associated with calorie intake.In the paper, council officers suggest that as the councilrsquos trading standards team already has experience around alcohol and tobacco restrictions, then it would lsquomake sense to utilise that expertisersquo.The draft response on enforcement, whichapproved will be sent to the Scottish Government, reads: ldquoLocal authorities have experience of similar enforcement regimes in relation to tobacco and nicotine vapour products and have had a role in the online pricing of alcohol following the implementation of the minimum pricing legislation.ldquoWhilst it would be for the local authority to determine which service is best placed to enforce the proposals, trading standards already have a role in policing pricing and it would make sense to utilise the expertise that already exists in the local authority.ldquoHowever, it should be recognised that there will be a need for Scottish Government to work with local authorities to quanty current and future resources required to police pricing promotions and to provide these to local authorities to reduce the inevitable additional burden that the proposed restrictions will create.In July  the Scottish Government produced a paper which set out the foods it felt needed to be targeted in order to reduce the caloric intake and weight of Scottish people.These include: confectionery sweet biscuits crisps savoury snacks cakes pastries puddings and soft drinks with added sugar.The consultation askslocal authorities agree with this list, and whether more items should be added.In their draft consultation response, Scottish Borders Council officers believe that ice-cream, ready meals and dairy desserts should also be included in the crackdown: ldquoWhile it will certainly be useful to target the discretionary foods listed above there is also a need to include drinks high in sugar, salt, fat or calories irrespective of whether or not this is lsquoaddedrsquo.ldquoSimilarly ice-cream and dairy desserts should also come under the scope of the new policy as they are often high in fat and high in sugar and do not form an essential dietary component.ldquoWhile diary-based desserts could offer some benefits in terms of calcium and other nutrients, these would be available from other sources in a healthy diet.ldquoTheir benefit in a dairy-based dessert would be offset by the high energy density and presence of salts, sugars and fats.According to the NHS Health Scotland, in ,  per cent of Scotlandrsquos children were at risk of becoming overweight, and  per cent were at risk of becoming obese. In ,  per cent of adults were overweight including  per cent obese.The NHS says that some of the health risks of being overweight include an increase chance of developing type  diabetes, heart disease, stroke, and some cancers.

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Chilly winter mornings lead usto spend an extra  hoursin bed over the colder months - just from hitting the snooze button.Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: 83-year-old-dick-drives-into-the-guinness-book-of-world-records
story: AN -year-old lorry driver from Ashkirk has just parked up on the pages of the Guinness Book of World Records.Dick Henderson has spent almost five decades behind the wheel for several local haulage firms.And on Saturday he was presented with the official Guinness Book of Records certicate during a surprise party.Dick, who was  years and  days old when he was officially certied as the oldest, beats the previous record which was held for  years by -year-old Robert Currie.Dick told us: "I never knew a thing about the record - it was all a big surprise when I went down for a pint on Saturday."I began driving when I was  on the Co-op coal lorry and thats what Ive been doing ever since."Ive no intention of stopping -I feel I cant do it any more Ill stop, but I dont see that happening for a while yet."Working le for Dick began on a farm just after the Second World War.In  he got his first taste of driving with the Cooperative coal lorry then for a lime delivery firm in Hawick.After a spell at Philiphaugh Estate in Selkirk, Dick worked for several local companies including Thomas Mitchell of Ettrickbridge.He did retire from Baxters of Pathead at the start of the millennium - for just TWO days.And he quickly got back in the driving seat with his sons firm, Elliot Hendersons, in Selkirk.Dick, who was widowed in the s, added: "Retirement wasnt for me."I was bored after two days and went back to work."On Saturday Dick was joined by sons Elliot and Roderick, and daughter Lesley, along with his grandchildren and great-grandchildren to celebrate his inclusion in the Guinness Book of World Records at The Smiddy in his home village.Former colleagues from Baxters also joined in the celebrations.Grandson Gavin, who works with his grandfather in Selkirk, organised the surprise party.He said: "We first contacted the Guinness World Records almost a year ago and its been a y process where they have to validate all of the paperwork to prove my granddad is the oldest."Hes remarkable for his age and I cant imagine his record will be beaten any time soon"

title: galas-ali-balie-bee-sweetseller-to-be-cast-in-bronze
story: THE search is on to put a face to the Galashiels man who penned the world-famous lullaby Ali Bali Bee.A statue to Coulters Candy originator Robert Coltart will be unveiled in his hometown this summer.But the people behind the le-sized bronze tribute are desperately trying to confirman old newspaper photograph sent from Canada is the weaver-turned-sweet seller.Historians Graeme McIver and Mary Craig have been championing Coltarts story for over a decade.And they are delighted that celebrated sculptor Angela Hunter is currently sketching designs for the tribute which will be placed in the towns Market Place.Graeme told us: "Coulterrsquos Candy is arguably Scotlandrsquos best known and most loved childrenrsquos song and it is fantastic that at long last there will be a permanent reminder."To coin a phrase we used during our research, lsquoAli Bali is actually from Guid Auld Galaersquo."The town has faced challenges in attracting new visitors and this statue, along with the other proposed regeneration works, will Irsquom sure provide a much needed boost for Galashiels.ldquoAngela Hunterrsquos work is fantastic and it has been a pleasure looking at her ideas for how the finished statue will look."I am sure it will become a much loved local attraction and will rekindle interest in the story of Robert Coltart and the song.Robert Coltart was born in Dumfries and Galloway and moved to Galashiels at a young age, like many at the time, to work in the mills.It was during the s that is thought he began making aniseed-flavoured toffee at his Overhaugh Street home.As well as doing a fine trade at fairs, he would sell his candy around the streets of his adopted hometown playing a whistle and singing his jingle - Ali Balie Bee - with a trail of children in his wake.Coltart also lived at houses in Henderson Close and Park Street, which have both since been demolished.And he was known to travel to nearby Melrose and Selkirk, as well as other Borders towns, to sell his candy on the streets - traders in Selkirk even raised a court order against him as he was taking away their trade.One report from the time states: "He wore a tam a shanter, or was it a Balmoral bonnet  With a pheasantrsquos feather sticking straight up from a buckle above his ear."A shiny black bag slung over his shoulder held stock of the famous candy!"While there are many descriptions of the larger-than-le Robert Coltart, who died in  at the age of , only one photograph is known to exist.And the researches, as well as sculptor Angela, are trying to have the image veried before the final detail is made to the bronze statue.Angela, whose work includes the iconic Turn bull bronze in Hawick, said: "We do have one newspaper cutting from the Gala Post, sent from Canada, and we are hoping to confirm this is Robert.ldquoIt is hoped that someone may have further information on his le, so we can make this sculpture as accurate as possible."I was born in Galashiels and am therefore incredibly proud to be involved in this project."Although the recipe for Coulters Candy was lost after Roberts death, his Ali Balie Bee jingle was passed through the generations.And after it began to be sung at folk nights all over the country in the s, eventually being recorded by Donovan in .The statue, which will feature Coltart selling his candy with two children by his side, will be erected close to his Overhaugh Street home at Market Square.The artwork is part of a new town trail, supported by the Scottish Governmentrsquos Regeneration Capital Grant Fund.The fund provided a pound.m grant last year, a proportion of which is being used to fund pound, of streetscape improvements.Among the supporters of the statue and trail is business councillor Mark Rowley.Councillor Rowley said: ldquoThe story of Robert Coltart is a fascinating one which should be known by more people and alongside the other regeneration works taking place in Galashiels, I am sure it will attract people to the town and the Borders.ldquoA partnership approach is being used to take forward the project with a iety of stakeholders from the local community and businesses involved in finalising the streetscape improvements as priorities."These improvement works would not have been possible without the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor complex, which helped secure the overall support from the Scottish Government Regeneration Grant Fund.ldquoThis year is to be an exciting one as Galashiels is re-shaped and investment encouraged in the town and the wider Borders economy as part of the Galashiels Masterplan.Helen Calder of Energise Galashiels Trust has also championed Coltartrsquos story.She added: ldquoWe are delighted to play our part in the telling of the story of Robert Coltart."Ali Bali is such a world-famous nursery rhyme that we see real opportunity in celebrating its link to our town.Robert Coltart was buried in an unmarked paupers grave at Eastland Cemetery.But his legacy willto his hometown in June with the unveiling of the bronze in Market Square.Anyone with further information or images of Coltart can contact Angela on angie@angelahunter.

title: channel-4-show-hunted-is-looking-for-borders-contestants
story: COULD you go on the run for a month and avoid being caught by former military and intelligence officers Wellthe answer is yes, Channel  is waiting to hear from Borderers to appear on TV show Hunted.Andyou can avoid being caught ndash youll be in for a hefty cash reward.A spokesperson for the programme said: "Were looking for aspiring fugitivesof all ages, men and women, to take part and do whatever it takes to disappear in st century Britain."Perhaps you fancy your chances by going it alone, or maybe yoursquod like to escape with your family, friends or colleagues."A prize of pound, will be shared equally between the fugitives who successfully evade capture."To apply, go to: http:www.huntedapplicationsThe closing date: Monday, February .

title: confused-commuters-have-world-turned-upside-down-in-galashiels
story: COMMUTERS had their world turned upside down in Galashiels last week.For four or five days confused bus passengers at the Transport Interchange struggled to read the real-time arrival and departure screens - as they were all upside down.And the confusion continued right through to the start of this week.Selkirk pensioner Jaye Riddell told us: "It was a bit dficult to make out when buses were due - I cant read upside down writing."There was one child lying on the ground trying to read the times out to to his grandparents."Thankfully the train timetables were the right way up."Scottish Borders Council is responsible for the large interactive timetable screens at the Transport Interchange.And their IT people managed to fix the upside-down problem on Monday.A spokesman told us: "The issue with the information boards has been resolved and everything is the right way up now."

title: ben-magowan-announced-as-melrosian-elect-for-2019
story: TAKING up the reins as this years Melrosian-Elect is a -year-old childrens nurse from Gattonside.Ben Magowan was announced in the role at the annual Ex-Melrosians Association Burns Supper on Saturday night.The former pupil of Melrose Primary, St Marys School and Earlston High said: "I was very nervous on the evening but its such an honour to be asked to be the Melrosian-Elect."It was an exciting evening and I had my family there to support me."Im already looking forward to the summer and have started learning about the other towns festivals."The Burns Supper was a sell-out and guests were entertained by Sandy Telfer who proposed the toast to the Immortal Memory followed by Harry Fletchers Toast to the Lassies and Annabel Crawfords reply. The toast to Town and Trade was proposed by Mark Robertson with Ex-Melrosian David Crawford replying. Russell Mackay proposed the vote of thanks to Michael Crawford for his rendition of Address to a Haggis, entertainers Drew Scott and Donald Swanson as well as special guest Jim Hutchison for performing Tam o Shanter. Thanks were also extended to the catering and bar staff at Melrose RFC.This years week-long Melrose Festival, which celebrates the history of the town, will take place June  until June  .The Rideout is on the June  and the Crowning of the Festival Queen is on Thursday, June .The Queen and Court for the festival will be appointed in May.

title: devon-based-hotel-group-buys-cringletie-house
story: AN award-winning country house hotel in Peeblesshire is about to change hands.Cringletie House Hotel, which was named AA Hotel of the Year for Scotland in , was placed on the market just over a year ago with an asking price of pound. million.The -bespoke-bedroom baronial retreat has been bought by Devon-based Cross Hotels Limited.And the official hand over will take place on February .Johanna and Jacob van Houdt have owned Cringletie for the past  years.Jacob told us: ldquoWe acquired Cringletie in a derelict state in  and invested time and money creating a destination for holidays in the Scottish Borders."Cringletie is now ready for a new phase of development and further growth."We are delighted that the Crossrsquos are bringing new energy and ideas to this magnicent project.Cringletie is set in  acres of land near Eddleston.As well as offering guests luxury room accommodation there is also a two-bedroom letting cottage in the grounds as well as staff accommodation.The hotel is also home to a -year-old walled garden and Dutch styled parterre garden.And there is also a large area of land available for further development.Bill Cross, Director of Cross Hotels, said: ldquoThe van Houdtrsquos have created a very stylish hotel at Cringletie House."We look forward to enhancing the operation and in due course extending the facilities."

title: mens-shed-goes-all-pc-with-eildon-donation
story: LOCAL social landlord Eildon Housing are setting a recycling example by donating old PCs and office furniture to a Mens Shed group.The Selkirk-based housing association handed over four computers as well as cupboards to Kelso Mens Shed last week.Eildons Chief Executive Nile Istephan told us: "As part of the on-going modernisation of our business processes, we had some surplus furniture and computers that we wanted to put to good use."In line with one of our corporate values of being connected to the communities that we work within, it is great that we can donate our surplus equipment to such a worthy cause.ldquoThe Menrsquos Shed movement provides the community with a very valuable service, by offering recreational facilities to help advance the social needs, health and well-being of people of all ages and backgrounds living in Kelso and surrounding areas."Along with a number of other organisations we have also provided financial support for a Menrsquos Shed Development worker to maximise the potential for this inspirational idea across our region.Kelso Mens Shed already has over  members.The organisation meets every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday between am and pm.Bob Stather from Kelso Menrsquos Shed added: ldquoWe are extremely grateful for this very kind donation which will be of enormous benefit to our new Shedders."Getting on-line will be a priority for some of our new members, and this will be made possible thanks to Eildonrsquos generous donation.

title: selkirk-woman-accused-of-embezzling-16k-from-mother-in-law
story: A SELKIRK woman has been accused of embezzlement at the towns sherf court.Kirsten Darling is alleged to have embezzled the sum of pound,.The -year-old is said to have been granted welfare and financial Power of Attorney along withher husband on behalf of her mother-in-law who was then suffering from dementia.The offence is said to have happened at her home in Leslie Place, between April and July last year.Thecase was continued without plea until February .

title: innerleithen-shoplifter-admits-trolley-dash-at-asda
story: AN INNERLEITHEN man stole groceries to the value of pound. from the ASDA superstore in Galashiels and then ran off after being confronted by a staff member.Peter Dawes, , of Craig Terrace, pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to the offence which happened on December .Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser explained how Dawes was challenged over a trolley of groceries after leaving the store and was asked what check-out he had paid for them at.He said: "He was asked to come back into the store and he bent down to tie his shoe lace and then ran off."Dawes then drove off from the car park but was traced by police because he was registered keeper of the vehicle.Mr Fraser added: "There was no success in the theft as there was a full recovery of the goods but it was a substantial amount he would have got away with."Defence lawyer Mat Patrick said: "He does not have any explanation why he has done this."He has no excuse for it."It was not a very sophisticated attempt of theft."Mr Patrick said his client had pleaded guilty at the first opportunity and there was a full recovery.Dawes was fined pound.

title: single-borderers-can-now-apply-to-appear-on-first-dates-hotel
story: MATCHMAKING managerFred Sirieix and the First Dates team are taking reservations at the First Dates Hotel for a new summer season of love in .The popular Channel  TV show sees the well-known maicirctre d take a break from the shows restaurant to take over the running of a luxury hotel abroad where he will welcome singletons from the UK on a two-day dating stay.Last year the show was filmed in Campania near Naples in Italy.Producers from the show help you find a partner from a pool of other singletons and captures the highs and lows of your first date on camera.At the end of the meal, couples will choose to split the bill, go home alone or spend the next day with your date at the hotels location which is yet to be revealed for this years series.A producer added: "Wersquore looking for singletons from across the UK to join us in Italy for a dose of La Dolce Vita as we match you on the most romantic date of your le."Each episode will feature a number of intimate first dates. title: violent-galashiels-teenager-sentenced-to-unpaid-work
story: A GALASHIELS teenager who admitted a series of violence offences has been ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work at Selkirk Sherf Court.Dario Durante, , pleaded guilty to punching a male repeatedly on the head in Church Square, Galashiels, on June .He also admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in the back of a police vehicle in Croft Street, Galashiels, and kicking parked vehicles and also bins in his home street on September .Durante also admitted kicking a female police officer on the leg at Tesco and struggling violently with other officers.

title: flytippers-carpeted-for-desecrating-pipers-grave
story: FLY-TIPPERS have desecrated the grave of a legendary th century piper from Peebles who met his tragic end after taking off on foot to play the pipes from Traquair to Edinburgh Castle.Locals have blasted inconsiderate dumpers who left rolled up carpets and tiles on the B granites road between Innerleithen and Gorebridge.One of the sites affected was the burial place of the itinerant piper who was known to frequent the local hostelries taking wagers that he could play any tune that a customer named.The tale goes that he played his final tune one drunken evening after taking a bet that he couldnt play non-stop on all the way to Edinburgh Castle.It is said that one of the crowd resorted to sabotage and cut a hole in the windbag of the pipes. The steep climb and extra effort required to play exhausted the piper who sat down never to rise again.It was at this very spot, midway between Innerleithen and Heriot that the piper was laid to rest.Disgusted by what he discovered on the roadside, local resident Nick Tokely said: ldquoOne of the five spots to have stuff dumped was the piperrsquos grave which is a scenic landmark. This time it was industrial amounts of carpet and carpet tiles, but its dferent items each week.

title: lottery-cash-to-expand-td1-youth-drop-ins
story: A GALASHIELS youth charity has been boosted with a windfall from the Scottish Childrens Lottery.TD Youth Hub has been awarded a pound, grant from the fund.TD Youth Hub supports young people in and around Galashiels by offering evening drop-ins, streetwork, young parents group, music projects, mentoring and physical activities.The Scottish Childrens Lottery cash will enable the charity to expand its drop-in service, which provides young people with a safe place to meet friends, speak to youth workers and relax.Douglas Ormston, TD Youth Hub Manager, said: "This grant from the Scottish Childrens Lottery is so important to our organisation."Our drop-ins provide us with opportunities to engage with young people, find out what their needs are and then plan projects and services which suit them, giving young people opportunities to shape their own positive futures.The Scottish Childrens Lottery was launched in October  to raise money for children in Scotland, with proceeds helping to improve the lives of children right across the country and make a real dference to those who need it most.Trustee Kirsteen Campbell said: ldquoI am delighted that we are able to provide funding for TD Youth Hub from the money generated from the Scottish Childrenrsquos Lottery, which was established in order to promote and support the development and potential of children and young people in Scotland."Thank you to those who play the Scottish Childrenrsquos Lottery - you are helping to support the great work that our charities undertake.

title: stobo-goes-third-generation-as-md-steps-down
story: IT is one of the most successful businesses in Peeblesshire.And after  years at the helm of Stobo Castle Health Spa, Stephen Winyard is handing over control to his two sons.The Winyard family bought the th century castle in the early s.Stephens parents Robert and Gaynor undertook a major makeover of the run-down castle - opening it as one of the countrys first health farms in .And a decade later Stephen took on the running of the business.At the height of srsquo fashion, it featured just  bedrooms with shared avocado bathroom suites, medical checks for guests and calorie-controlled meals.Since then, signicant investment has taken place and a poundmilion state-of-the-art spa extension in  led to the creation of  treatment rooms, a fully-equipped gym, saunas, steam rooms, a stunning -metre ozone-treated infinity pool and outdoor hot tubs.Guests are often found sipping bubbly between rejuvenating spa and beauty treatments, exploring the outdoor Japanese water garden or dining in the wood-led dining room.The addition of the stunning Cashmere Suite complete with cashmere lined walls and original works of Scottish art, cashmere-covered hand-made Italian beds and an opulent bathroom with its famed pound, hand-carved bath for a single piece of limestone, has proved another lure. It is widely acknowledged as the most opulent guest suite in the land.More recently, the new Ladies Restroom made the headlines as Scotlandrsquos most luxurious loos.Last year Stobo recorded a pre-tax profit of over pound million.And with planned future investment, the luxury spa resort is forecast to go from strength-to-strength.Last week Mr Winyard officially announced that he will step aside from his managing director role to become chairman of the business.But Stobo Castle will remain firmly in family hands with his son Elliot becoming managing director and other son Mitchell taking on the position of projects director.Stephenrsquos we Mandy will continue in her role as a director of the company.Stephen told us: ldquoStobo Castlersquos evolution from what was basically a derelict property, has been remarkable."My mother was chairman of the Society of Health and Beauty Therapists at the time. She had a vision that it could become a health farm, at a time when such places were virtually unheard of."Today Stobo Castle is Scotlandrsquos only destination spa and one of many peoplersquos lsquomust visitrsquo places to relax and rejuvenate."Sadly, my parents are no longer alive to see it, however its success is testimony to their incredible vision and hard work."Stobo Castlersquos staff have also contributed immensely to its success, many of whom have been here almost since the beginning.

title: scottish-borders-council-in-line-for-more-cash
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council could be in for a larger settlement grant than first expected following a deal between rival parties in Holyrood.A new funding settlement for local authorities has been agreed in the Scottish parliament following a last-minute deal between the majority Scottish National Party and minority Greens ahead of a vote on the annual budget.The deal includes more core funding for councils and extra powers for them to levy local parking and tourist taxes.Derek MacKay, the Scottish Governmentrsquos finance secretary, first unveiled proposals for the budget in December , including added funding for schools and the National Health Service, as well as increasing income tax for those earning pound, or more.Opposition parties moved to block the bid, partly due to the SNP refusing to rule out calling another independence referendum and also because they say the budget would result in a poundm funding cut for local authorities.However, the deal with the Scottish Greens means the budget is now likely to be passed.Scottish Borders Council leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoThis settlement does go some way to mitigating the cuts that we were expecting. However, it has a narrow focus in terms of local taxation.ldquoGiven the consultation only concluded last Friday, it is surprising that the Scottish Government were able to announce the tourist tax today.The new deal with the Scottish Greens includes an extra poundm for the core local government settlement, a move to three-year local authority budgets and legislation that will give councils control over tourism taxes.The deal also includes raising the council tax cap, meaning local authorities will now be able to increase council tax by .%, up from %.Fellow Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, also leader of the councilrsquos Scottish national party opposition group , said: ldquoSignicant announcements have been made on a phased development of alternatives to the council tax. ldquoAlthough I donrsquot advocate that locally we should immediately take advantage of the proposal to give local authorities power to introduce a tourist tax, or the suggested workplace parking levy, these are adjustments that some Scottish city authorities will want to take up after the necessary legislation is approved.ldquoI am also pleased that talks on meaningful alternatives to council tax will restart and that with a three-year funding settlement, as opposed to the current one-year deals, there will be more clarity for local authorities on future funding.ldquoThere are also small changes in the - revenue grants for local authorities. Despite the constant chant of despair from the Bordersrsquo Tories, I said all along that the December announcements of funding for the council were only provisional. ldquoThe Conservatives who lead the council like to highlight that we were told we might see pound.m less for core revenue funding next year, conveniently forgetting to talk about promised money for new services such as the massive expansion in early learning and childcare.ldquoThey also omit to tell Borderers that we are getting poundm more next year as capital funding, almost exactly offsetting the change in revenue funding.ldquoWe must wait until the detail of the poundm package from the Scottish Government is analysed by officers, but my provisional calculation is that the new funding announcements could give the council more than pound.m, meaning that we will see a clear cash increase in next yearrsquos funding for core revenue and capital.ldquoSadly, we are being told that the Conservatives in Holyrood may vote against these welcome changes.Rachael Hamilton, Conservative MSP for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, said: ldquoThanks to the SNP, Scots across the country are about to be hit by a triple tax bombshell.ldquoThis budget not only taxes aspiration but taxes people for driving to work, which is quite frankly ridiculous in a constituency like mine, where travelling by car is essential.ldquoWe will pay the highest income taxes in the UK, council tax could go up and now you might even be taxed hundreds of pounds a year for taking your car to work.ldquoThe SNP have run out of ideas on how to grow and expand the economy. Instead, they have decided to raid the pockets of hard-working families.,params: .pushMr Bell added: ldquoMy big message to the Borders Tories is to drop their mentality of dependence and to take responsibility for balancing a Borders budget. ldquoThe power to make change is in the hands of the council and they should stop trying to shirk local responsibility. Power to finance - expenditure is in the hands of the administration.ldquoDerek MacKay has announced that more could be raised from further increasing the local council tax to a new upper level of over %, as the Scottish Government has lted the previous cap.ldquoFurther, the Tory-led Borders administration should take responsibility for properly managing our councilrsquos affairs. ldquoFigures I have seen show that there are unrealised savings of over pound.m that were planned in last yearrsquos budget which have not been realised in practice.ldquoIf these saving had been made, then there would be less cuts this year. If we hadnrsquot poured it away in unrealised savings and could add this new money, perhaps the Bordersrsquo revenue finances would balance. ldquoWhat is the point in giving the administration any more moneythey canrsquot properly manage what we now get. They must stop blaming everyone  and put their own affairs in order.What do you think Send us your views for our letters page, including your name and address, here

title: scottish-borders-council-food-crackdown
story: A CRACKDOWN on the sale of Selkirk bannocks, Scotch pies, fried haggis and battered Mars Bars could soon be in the works as Scottish Borders Council has indicated it is prepared to target unhealthy foods.As part of a Scottish Government consultation, the local authority has indicated to Holyrood that its trading standards officers could potentially take on a larger role policing the selling and marketing of high-fat, high-sugar and high-salt foods.In July , ministers at Holyrood produced a paper setting out the foods they feel need to be targeted in order to reduce the caloric intake and weight of Scots.These include confectionery, sweet biscuits, crisps, savoury snacks, cakes, pastries, puddings and soft drinks with added sugar.The consultation askslocal authorities agree with this list and whether more items should be added.The councilrsquos consultation response, drafted by Keith Allan of NHS Borders, states that the authority believes ice-cream, ready meals and dairy desserts should also be included in the crackdown, explaining: ldquoWhile it will certainly be useful to target the discretionary foods listed above, there is also a need to include drinks high in sugar, salt, fat or calories irrespective of whether or not this is added.ldquoSimilarly, ice-cream and dairy desserts should also come under the scope of the new policy as they are often high in fat and high in sugar and do not form an essential dietary component.ldquoWhile dairy-based desserts could offer some benefits in terms of calcium and other nutrients, these would be available from other sources in a healthy diet.ldquoTheir benefit in a dairy-based dessert would be offset by the high-energy density and presence of salts, sugars and fats.At a full meeting of the council today, January , councillors voted in favour of approving the officerrsquos draft response despite criticism and concerns from some councillors.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing, a health worker, was strongly in favour of the consultation response, saying: ldquoI have worked in the adult health service my entire adult le, and I have seen first hand the impact on peoplersquos wellbeing of poor diet and the suffering it causes.ldquoIn my current role, there is barely a day that goes by without discussing with a parent or carer the impact of sugar in their childrenrsquos food, but, letrsquos face it, fat, salt and sugar make thing taste nice, and itrsquos easy to fall into the trap of overindulgence.ldquoThatrsquos okay every now and again, but regular overindulgence of fat, sugar and salt leads to grave consequences, such as tooth decay, heart disease, diabetes and cancer.ldquoObesity, including childhood obesity, is fast becoming the epidemic of our age.ldquoMany of us are blissfully unaware just how much salt, sugar and fat is in the foods we buy.ldquoBig companies which produce, promote and retail these products are in it to maximise profits. They have at their disposal expensive advertising and marketing which hugely influence our choices and purchasing habits.,params: .pushHowever, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott felt the proposals amounted to unwelcome government meddling with personal choice, saying: ldquoIrsquom not in agreement with any of the proposals in this paper. I appreciate the problem, but this is typical nanny state, dictating to us how we should live our lives.ldquoIt will cause unnecessary restrictions on business, specialist retailers will find it hard to market themselves, and I doubt very much whether it will have any impact on the groups it is targeting.ldquoWhilst Irsquom very much in favour of labelling food to make clearer to the consumers whatrsquos in it, in principle I am against compulsion. People have to take responsibility for their own lives and lestyle choices, and as long as you keep within the law, the state should have no place in telling you what you can eat or drink.A motion put forward by Mr Scott called for the response to be completely rejected, but it was not supported by his fellow councillors.Instead, they opted to vote to submit the consultation response in full, albeit as a council officer response not as a political response.According to NHS Health Scotland, in , % of Scotlandrsquos children were at risk of becoming overweight and % were at risk of becoming obese. That same year, % of adults were overweight, almost half of them being classed as obese.The NHS says that some of the health risks of being overweight include an increased chance of developing type-two diabetes and a greater risk of heart disease, stroke and some cancers.What do you think Send us your views for our letters page, including your name and address, here

title: pothole-plea-to-boost-borders-cycle-tourism
story: A SCOTTISH Borders councillor has been taking the council to task over the state of the regionrsquos roads, raising fears it could impact on the regionrsquos cycling tourism economy.Galashiels and District councillor Harry Scott has raised issues with the council about the state of the B Heriot to Innerleithen road, designated as a cycling route but, he says, in ldquoa state of serious disrepair.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday  January, councillor Scott asked for the road to be resurfaced: ldquoThe B Heriot to Innerleithen road is listed as an official Borders cycle route with the aim ofattracting touring cyclists to enjoy the scenery and spend money in the Borders.ldquoSeveral sections of the road, particularly towards Innerleithen are presently in a state of serious disrepair, and hazardous not only for cars, but particularly for cyclists.ldquoMay I ask that at the least the most hazardous sections of the B be considered for inclusion as a matter of priority in the roads departmentrsquos scheme of works and overlays for the year  .In response, Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, told the chamber: ldquoThe road is inspected every two months in accordance with the councilrsquos policy and standards guidelines.ldquoAny defects noted during these inspections are recorded and instructions are issued to carry out reactive maintenance as required within the timescale guidelines.ldquoMaintenance of the councilrsquos adopted road network is programmed by our asset team.ldquoSome sections of the B road are listed as lsquobeing considered for possible inclusionrsquo in future surface treatment programmes.ldquoUnfortunately, the overall condition of our roads network means that we are not in a position to agree to treat all identied sections with a permanent form of treatment and must apply a prioritisation process to determine an annual programme which means our annual budget.In a prepared statement, councillor Scott said: ldquoMy reasons are that we are selling the Scottish Borders to tourists, cycling being one of the strands.ldquoThe B leads from the Edinburgh and Lothians area to the heart of Borders cycling in the Innerleithen and Peebles areas.ldquoLike any tourists we hope that they will extend their stay and their exploration of the Borders from that base.ldquoThe B is no better or worse than many of our other roads, and Irsquom not looking for a quick fixes because in the current financial climate, there are none.ldquoIrsquom simply asking that the road is not forgotten in the work schedule, and that at the least the worst sections can be identied for improvement or repair.What do you think Send us your views for our title: business-brunch-whets-appetite-for-languages
story: YOUNG people from four Borders schools have taken part in a business and languages event.S and S students from Earlston High, Jedburgh Grammar, Kelso High and Peebles High joined  learners from across the Edinburgh, Lothians and Borders areas for the Business Brunch in Edinburghs Dynamic Earth.The event on January  demonstrated the relevance of language skills in a work context and aimed to encourage pupils to continue with their language studies into the senior phase of their secondary education and beyond.Pupils heard from a range of business leaders who view language skills as key to the growth and success of their company.A teacher attending the event said: ldquoTodayrsquos event has opened my learnersrsquo eyes to languages as a key skill for work in all industries, and as something to enrich their lives.One of the young people added to this, and commented: ldquoI learnt that languages are useful for everything, including my personal le. I also discovered that knowing a language makes you a lot more employable. I didnt expect places like Dynamic Earth to have languages as one of their work experience opportunities.Lynn Houmdi from Maroc-o-phile and one of the speakers, stated: ldquoThe event was really well-organised. I chatted to people on a few of the stands and was really impressed that so many companies and organisations are actively seeking language skills.Sophie Dawes, Project Officer at Developing the Young WorkforceEdinburgh, Midlothian and East Lothian regional group, and one of the organisers, stated: ldquoGiving young people an opportunity to hear directly from businesses across a broad range of sectors highlighted why continuing with languages at school could be so beneficial to opening up a world of opportunities beyond school. With a iety of industry led workshops and exhibitors speaking directly with young people, everyone had opportunities to be informed and inspired."The day was action packed from start to finish and the feedback received from young people and teachers has been so positive. Wersquore already looking forward to planning for !The event was organised by SCILT, Scotlandrsquos National Centre for Languages based at University of Strathclyde, in partnership with Developing the Young WorkforceEdinburgh, Midlothian, East Lothian, West Lothian and Borders regional groups together with the University Council for Modern Languages Scotland .Fhiona Mackay, Director of SCILT said: ldquoIn these times of uncertainty, it is even more important than ever that we equip our young people with the skills they will need for le beyond school. We want them to be outward-looking and able to operate in an interdependent world. Events such as these highlight the importance of language skills and intercultural competencies in the world of work.ldquoThe business leaders who speak at these events give of their own time because they understand how much these skills are needed and valued by employers and how vital they are for Scotlandrsquos business community. This kind of collaboration is an example of how education and business sectors can work together for their mutual benefit so that we can support young people and help them develop the portfolio of skills that employers require in their workforce.

title: msp-urges-borders-women-to-have-smear-tests
story: A REGIONAL MSP is encouraging women in the Borders to attend regular smear tests.Claudia Beamishhas joined charity Jorsquos Cervical Cancer Trustrsquos campaign to get more people going to screenings more often.She told us: ldquoLast year cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from . per cent to . per cent which means more than one in four eligible women missed their screen test.ldquoYet regular screening prevents up to  per cent of cervical cancers developing.ldquoThe statistics are particularly worrying for younger women where uptake is only  per cent despite the fact cervical cancer is the most common cancer for women aged under .ldquoI know going for a smear test isnrsquot easy, it can be uncomfortable and awkward but it is so important to attend appointments and I urge people not to put them off. Testing really can save lives.For more information about cervical cancer and the campaign, visit JosTrust.org.uk

title: uk-could-see-coldest-night-in-almost-a-decade-as-big-freeze-continues
story: The big freeze will continue to grip much of Britain, with the mercury poised to drop so low the UK could see its coldest night in almost a decade.But the plummeting temperatures will be short lived, with milder air expected to push its way across the country from Sunday, the Met Office said.Thick blankets of snow caused widespread disruption and treacherous conditions across vast swathes of southern Britain on Thursday and Friday.With cm recorded in some parts, motorists were stranded in their vehicles, hundreds of schools were closed, and travellers were hit by long delays and cancelled flights.The heavy snowfall even caused some trees and branches in Kent to collapse and snap under the weight ndash cascading into road and over pavements.Todays winter sunshine has revealed title: brexit-played-inevitable-role-in-nissan-x-trail-decision-says-mp
story: Brexit played an ldquoinevitable role in the reported decision by Nissan to abandon plans to build its X-Trail model at its Sunderland plant, an MP has said.According to Sky News, the company will confirm the move to cancel plans to build the new version of the SUV on Monday, just  days before Britain is scheduled to leave the EU.Unitersquos assistant general secretary for manufacturing, Steve Turner, said the ldquorumours are disturbing and many of the workforce will endure a ldquovery anxious weekend.Sunderland Central Labour MP Julie Elliott said Nissan is yet to officially announce the move, but that the ldquoinevitable role Brexit has played cannot be denied.ldquoThe constant uncertainty, the chaotic government. None of it is conducive to encouraging business investment in this country, she added.While Labour MP for Houghton and Sunderland South, Bridget Phillipson, saidthe move is confirmed it would ldquorepresent deeply troubling news for the North East economy.Tory Remainer Anna Soubry tweeted that it was ldquodficult not to be angry at the reports, adding: ldquoThis is Brexit reality.Nissan had voiced concerns about Brexit before finally committing to build the new Qashqai and X-Trail models in its North East factory in October , four months after the EU referendum.What we are hearing is that #Nissanis no longer planning on building its new X-Trail model in #Sunderland, despite whatever secret assurances it was given by the government. title: pro-brexit-mp-makes-totally-false-claim-about-europe-after-ww2-on-twitter
story: An MP has been accused of making a ldquototally  statement to his followers on Twitter about Europe and Britain after the Second World War.Daniel Kawczynski, the pro-Brexit Conservative backbencher for Shrewsbury, claimed in a tweet that there was ldquono Marshall Plan for us only for Germany, referring to American payments of more than pound billion approved in  to help rebuild Europe.ldquoDan is categorically wrong about the Marshall Plan, said Dr Warren Dockter, an American expert in British history and lecturer in international politics at Aberystwyth University, echoing hundreds of people on social media pointing out Mr Kawczynskirsquos error.Quoting from The Marshall Plan: Fty Years After, a seminal academic book on the subject, Dr Dockter said Britain received % of Marshall Plan donations, more than any other country.France received % and West Germany received %, he said.ldquoIn addition to Marshall Plan money, the UK received favourable loans and grants on top of the Marshall Plan aid, he told the Press Association.Britain made its last repayment on the Marshall Plan loans in .Is this a parody account  Britain received billions from the Marshall Plan and signicantly more than West Germany or any other nation. Pick up a history book and you will learn that this brand of jingoistic nationalism is what tore our continent apart twice in one century. https:t.co dIeuzRYaznmdash David LammyFebruary , Mr Kawczynskirsquos full tweet reads: ldquoBritain helped to liberate half of Europe. She mortgaged herself up to eye balls in process. No Marshall Plan for us only for Germany. We gave up war reparations in . We put pound billion into EU since we joined. Watch the way ungrateful EU treats us now. We will remember.ldquoThe British essentially waived their rights to collect World War Two reparations from Germany in , said Dr Charlotte Riley, an expert in modern British history, explaining that the decision came as part of an agreement when the country reunied.The source of Mr Kawczynskirsquos ldquopound billion claim is not clear and he did not respond to requests for comment.Some of Mr Kawczynskirsquos political colleagues were among the hundreds of people highlighting his error on social media.Labour MP David Lammy tweeted: ldquoIs this a parody account ldquoBritain received billions from the Marshall Plan and signicantly more than West Germany or any other nation. Pick up a history book and you will learn that this brand of jingoistic nationalism is what tore our continent apart twice in one century.Irish politician Thomas Byrne wrote simply: ldquoTotally  tweet from a British MP about the Marshall Plan and the UK.Totally  tweet from a British MP about the Marshall Plan and the UK. https:t.co GmvEvYrcmdash Thomas Byrne TDFebruary , This is not the first time Mr Kawczynski has been taken to task for inaccurate claims he has made on social media.In September , he posted a photograph of himself holding lemons in a supermarket alongside a caption claiming the ldquoEU protectionist racket means inefficient EU growers [are] preferred to other non EU Mediterranean growers, due to massive tarfs imposed by EU.Tarfs are taxes placed on imported goods to make domestic produce more appealing by making imports more expensive.But a self-described ldquotarf nerd and ldquoRemainiac pointed out that large amounts of the UKrsquos supply of citrus fruits are imported from countries like South Africa and Mexico which have a free trade deal with the EU and therefore % tarfs.And heres some lemons and limes from Sainsburys. Again the lemons are coming in on a % tarf because we have an FTA with South Africa. The limes are from Mexico. title: letter wild salmon migration
story: It was recently reported that the Scottish Gamekeepers Associationis calling for a ban on fish farms being built on wild salmon migration routes.The SGA fishing group believe careful positioning of proposed farms and re-siting problem pens could stop wild stocks being infested with parasites‎.Crown Estate Scotland, under the Freedom of InformationAct ‎, confirmed MOWI, formerly known as Marine Harvest, has a lease option agreement to a third site in the Kilbrannan Sound.This is a short term conditional agreement, for a secure and exclusive interest, that can be exercised for a full lease once all necessary consents # including planning permission and the marine licence have been secured.With the planned expansion, by an increase of  per cent, of the two existing MOWI sites, at Carradale and a third site at Cour Point, Kilbrannan Sound will be home to the single largest concentration of fish farm pens and salmon biomass in Europe.The SGA believe sea lice outbreaks from salmon farms contribute to the collapse of wild salmon stocks.A spokesperson said: #While a healthy salmon can survive with a burden of sealice, the high number of lice found in captive areas can lead to weakness and death.#Does Argyll and Bute Council and the Scottish Government acknowledge both the impact of sea lice and the subsequent use of chemicals, presently being felt in the Kilbrannan Sound An impact not only on wild salmon and sea trout stocks also our very localised lobster, crab and prawn fishing industry In past decades Kilbrannan Sound would have been described as a super highway for migrating wild salmon.Legislation in Norway, and recently British Colombia, does not permit the siting of fish farms on recognised wild salmon migration routes.Is it the local authority and national government#s intention to down grade the Sound, once plentul in fish and crustaceans alike, to that of a backwater trickle Tommy Macpherson,Saddell.

story: Friday January  Carradale poem at London ZooA poem created by a Carradale Primary School pupil has appeared on the front cover of a book which is set to be displayed at London Zoo.Along with Michaela Richard#s poem, pictures that were drawn by Jordan McKenzie and Raymond Gosling of primary five and Michael Charlwood of primary seven also appeared in the booklet.The frog poem folio impressed the director of the Zoological Society of London, David Field, who expressed a wish to display the poems and pictures at the zoo.The poem was read out and the pictures shown to about  people at Halting the Global Decline in Amphibians, a symposium dinner at London Zoo recently.Clockwise from left: Raymond Gosling, Jordan McKenzie, Michael Charlwood and Michaela Richards. _cfiles_Carradale_Pupils YEARS AGOFriday February  This time it#s warJoyriders face the wrath of taxi bossA Campbeltown taxi boss hopes to hunt down joyriders who stole one of his cars # by offering an award for information on the thieves.The distinctive Red Cabs vehicle # a white Montego with a red stripe, registration number D WBB # was stolen, from outside the Dellwood Hotel, around midnight last Thursday.And now Terry Meachem wants information leading to the conviction of the culprits, with £ on offer as the reward.The car was found hours later in the middle of the road to Peninver, facing Campbeltown.Red Cabs driver, and N and M Motors mechanic, Donald Brown, is pictured diagnosing serious damage to the gearbox which could cost as much as £ to repair.#Someone is bound to have seen it,# an irate Terry told the Courier, #and the money is there for information on who stole it.#Not only was the car badly damaged, but we#re losing money with the car being out of action.#This sort of thing is sickening, and whoever did it deserves all that is coming to them.#The Dellwood Hotel is at the entrance to the town on the West Road, and residents say they heard a car, believed to be the taxi, leaving at around . YEARS AGOJanuary  City honour for Mrs MacdonaldMrs Anne Maxwell Macdonald, we of Captain John Macdonald, the Laird of Largie, is to receive the freedom of Glasgow #in recognition of her deep interest in the cultural and civic le of the city.#Lord Provost Mr John Johnston proposed the honour and received the unanimous support of his magistrate colleagues. The corporation#s approval will be given today and the freedom ceremony will take place some time before May.Mrs Maxwell Macdonald, with the exception of royalty, is only the second woman to receive the freedom of the city, the previous recipient being Madame Curie, who was honoured in .Her father, the late Sir John Stirling-Maxwell, Bt., received the freedom of Glasgow in .It is thought to be unique that two members of the same family should receive the freedom. title: a kintyre music club review
story: By David O McEwanA pair of internationally recognised musicians visited Campbeltown for Kintyre Music Club#s first concert of .Cellist Jamal Aliyev from Azerbaijan and pianist Jâms Coleman, from Anglesey in North Wales, presented four pieces, at the recent Lorne and Lowland Hall event.The programme featured works by Beethoven Bloch and Bridge.The G minor cello sonata by Beethoven unfolded in typical fashion, with lots of contrasts in mood and speed, and revealed the assured technical and expressive abilities of both performers.Similarly in the Variations by the same composer it was clear that both performers were working as equals rather than as soloist and accompanist.The Bridge Cello Sonata pushed the boundaries of traditional harmonies and structure to the limits but always drew back from total dissonance.Once again the total mastery of their instruments was revealed by the performers.Perhaps the most attractive part of the programme was the #Three pieces from Jewish Le# by Bloch.These captured the spirit and soul of Judaism so well.The Swan by Saint-Saëns concluded the evening as a well-received encore.Cellist Jamal Aliyev and pianist Jâms Coleman with David O McEwan turning the pages during the concert. _cmusicclub_Jamal_Aliyev

title: down memory lane january 25 2019
story: Stephen Laing, assisted by his cousin, Glasgow academic and author Willy Maley, has found details and photographs of his aunt Anne Maley , working in the Women’s Land Army at Glenbarr during the Second World War. Anne passed away in  and her nephew has been researching family history.Stephen, who has posted a set of pictures to the Facebook page ‘Old Campbeltown and Surrounding Area,’ said: ‘Willy is the brains in our family, he’s been a great help to me. I am compiling a family tree and history.‘I have no family link to Kintyre and it was great to find out that my aunt Anne was in this area, at Rosehill Farm, in the war working on one of the farms.’In response to Down Memory Lane’s interest, Willy said: ‘That would make my mammy very happy.’In a short story Anne Maley wrote, one paragraph stated: ‘I never had any fear of animals in the old days. title: window wanderland goes under the sea
story: The theme for this year#s Magical Neighbourhood Walking Trail, on March  and , as suggested by some of CPH’s Facebook followers, is the sea.CPH is inviting everyone who has a window – houses, shop fronts, classrooms, cars, boats, sheds # to get creative and make a display according to the theme.The event is completely free and can be explored and enjoyed by the whole community, whether that is as window-makers or wanderers.The event is fun, creative, inclusive and gives the community an incentive to explore their neighbourhood on a dark winter’s evening and enjoy it in a whole new light.Window Wanderland was started in Bristol in February  by Lucy Reeves to help bring communities together, ward off isolation and spread happiness in the gloom of winter.Anyone can take part and almost anything can be a display from a string of fairy lights to a band playing in the living room, as long as it is family friendly, anything goes.There were  displays last year, when the theme was #cinema#, including a room transformed into Pandora from Avatar, a precise paper-cut Batman, hand-knitted Minions, nursery displays, balloons and inflatables in Campbeltown Town Hall, superheroes, Disney characters and much more.Cinema manager Ellen Mainwood said: #We had a great weekend last year with our first Window Wanderland. There were some brilliant displays, and people really enjoyed getting out and about to see them.#It’s fun and easy to join in, so we hope lots of people will get involved this year.#Participants get a welcome pack when they sign up and access to lots of inspiration.There will be free materials available and drop-in workshops to help window-makers with their displays at the cinema on March  and .Wanderers can see where the decorated windows are on an online map and CPH will have printed copies available during the event.Cinema staff can help window-makers sign upthey do not have access to the website or need some assistance.Those with questions, or who would like to sponsor, promote or help with the event should contact Ellen by emailing manager@campbeltownpicturehouseFor more information and to sign up, visit https:www.windowwanderland event campbeltown- A living room transformed into Pandora from Avatar.
