title: pro-brexit-mp-makes-totally-false-claim-about-europe-after-ww2-on-twitter
story: Daniel Kawczynski, the pro-Brexit Conservative backbencher for Shrewsbury, claimed in a tweet that there was ldquono Marshall Plan for us only for Germany, referring to American payments of more than pound billion approved in  to help rebuild Europe.ldquoDan is categorically wrong about the Marshall Plan, said Dr Warren Dockter, an American expert in British history and lecturer in international politics at Aberystwyth University, echoing hundreds of people on social media pointing out Mr Kawczynskirsquos error.Quoting from The Marshall Plan: Fty Years After, a seminal academic book on the subject, Dr Dockter said Britain received % of Marshall Plan donations, more than any other country.France received % and West Germany received %, he said.ldquoIn addition to Marshall Plan money, the UK received favourable loans and grants on top of the Marshall Plan aid, he told the Press Association.Britain made its last repayment on the Marshall Plan loans in .Is this a parody account  Britain received billions from the Marshall Plan and signicantly more than West Germany or any other nation. Pick up a history book and you will learn that this brand of jingoistic nationalism is what tore our continent apart twice in one century. https:t.co dIeuzRYaznmdash David LammyFebruary , Mr Kawczynskirsquos full tweet reads: ldquoBritain helped to liberate half of Europe. She mortgaged herself up to eye balls in process. No Marshall Plan for us only for Germany. We gave up war reparations in . We put pound billion into EU since we joined. Watch the way ungrateful EU treats us now. We will remember.ldquoThe British essentially waived their rights to collect World War Two reparations from Germany in , said Dr Charlotte Riley, an expert in modern British history, explaining that the decision came as part of an agreement when the country reunied.The source of Mr Kawczynskirsquos ldquopound billion claim is not clear and he did not respond to requests for comment.Some of Mr Kawczynskirsquos political colleagues were among the hundreds of people highlighting his error on social media.Labour MP David Lammy tweeted: ldquoIs this a parody account ldquoBritain received billions from the Marshall Plan and signicantly more than West Germany or any other nation. Pick up a history book and you will learn that this brand of jingoistic nationalism is what tore our continent apart twice in one century.Irish politician Thomas Byrne wrote simply: ldquoTotally  tweet from a British MP about the Marshall Plan and the UK.Totally  tweet from a British MP about the Marshall Plan and the UK. https:t.co GmvEvYrcmdash Thomas Byrne TDFebruary , This is not the first time Mr Kawczynski has been taken to task for inaccurate claims he has made on social media.In September , he posted a photograph of himself holding lemons in a supermarket alongside a caption claiming the ldquoEU protectionist racket means inefficient EU growers [are] preferred to other non EU Mediterranean growers, due to massive tarfs imposed by EU.Tarfs are taxes placed on imported goods to make domestic produce more appealing by making imports more expensive.But a self-described ldquotarf nerd and ldquoRemainiac pointed out that large amounts of the UKrsquos supply of citrus fruits are imported from countries like South Africa and Mexico which have a free trade deal with the EU and therefore % tarfs.And heres some lemons and limes from Sainsburys. Again the lemons are coming in on a % tarf because we have an FTA with South Africa. The limes are from Mexico. They also come in on a % tarf, because we have an FTA with Mexico. pic kQiEIdEcmdash Jim Cornelius#### #WATONSeptember , Prime Minister Theresa Mayis due to report back to Parliament on her negotiations with the EU on February , with a further series of votes by MPs expected the following day.

title: glasgow-airport-rail-link-to-be-ditched-for-rapid-shuttle-pod-to-paisley
story: A Personal Rapid Transit shuttle pod between Glasgow Airport and Paisley Gilmour Street has emerged as the likely alternative to a full tram-train rail link.Following a meeting between Glasgow and Renfrewshire council leaders, the Transport Secretary and Glasgow Airport yesterday, it has been agreed to work on a business case for the Personal Rapid Transit system.It would see passengers board the pods like ones used at Heathrow Airport to take them to the station at Paisley where they would catch existing services to Glasgow and where.AYE OR NAW, MICHAEL :Our message to transport secretary amid fresh fears over airport rail linkThe final choice will be between the tram-train option and the Personal Rapid Transit pod.It is, however, likely that the rapid transit option will be the preferred one and the option taken forward.The tram-train link hit problems following a study that said it would impact negatively on other services in the West of Scotland and on Central Station which is at capacity.The Evening Times message to the transport secretary earlier this monthSusan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoImproved connectivity to Glasgow Airport is a key priority. However, the advice from officers and consultants is that signicant questions remain about the deliverability of the current tram-train option, particularly in relation to capacity at Central Station.ldquoAs a result, the Executive Steering Group has agreed additional work should be done to establish an alternative Outline Business Case for a Personal Rapid Transitoption.ldquoThis work was not advanced by the previous City Deal Cabinet, but it is now crucial in order to allow us to make a fully-informed choice about which of the options in front of us should be progressed.:Glasgow Airport rail link saga has dragged on for far too longldquoI remain committed to a solution that delivers improved public transport connectivity to Glasgow Airport - but I am determined it should also provide value for money for the city, and deliver the widest possible inclusive economic benefits.ldquoIrsquom confident we have made signicant progress towards that outcome today.Glasgow Airport said congestion on the M means action is needed and ldquodoing nothing is not an option.Mark Johnston, managing director at Glasgow Airport, said: ldquoWe were informed that, due to issues around rail capacity, the project partners are developing an alternative option.: Half a million to go on addressing airport rail link fearsldquoThis will be evaluated and we will, of course, work with the partners to promote the delivery of an effective solution within the agreed timescale.It has been understood that transport officials were not keen on progressing the tram-train link from Glasgow Central to the airport.Michael Matheson, Transport Secretary, said: ldquoItrsquos crucial that improving access to Glasgow Airport is balanced with the needs of the regionrsquos existing transport network.ldquoThe Personal Rapid Transit system option potentially meets this aim, and I look forward to seeing the revised business case once itrsquos completed.

title: threads-of-life-a-history-of-the-world-through-the-eye-of-a-needle
story: #In the s,you couldn#t make your own clothes, you looked like your mother#Textile Artist Clare Hunter Picture: Kirsty Anderson Born in Glasgow in , Hunter attributes her lelong fascination with textiles to her mother, who organised those craft shop outings as ldquoa treat and spent hours patiently instructing young Clare in sewing techniques # perhaps, Hunter now thinks, as a way of keeping her quiet.Buther mother thought she was encouraging docility in her inquisitive daughter, she was mistaken. For although Hunter took to the needle with gusto, it was hardly in the spirit of conformity. Back in what she describes as a ldquofashion-starved s Glasgow, ldquo you couldnt sew your own clothes you looked like your mother and Hunter clearly had no intention of doing that. Instead, shed rustle up a party outfit overnight, sometimes getting her sister to stitch her into the garmentthere wasnt time to sew on fastenings.For Hunter, the needle became a weapon of empowerment rather than subjugation. In  years working as a community textile artist, she has helped marginalised women, striking miners and impoverished communities to express identity, dissent and protest through thread. And as her new book, Threads Of Le, makes clear, people have been quietly subverting this supposedly gentle art for centuries.When we meet in the Glasgow Womens Library surrounded by bold and beautul feminist banners, it becomes plain that for Hunter, pursuing a career in textiles was a rebellious act in itself. ldquoI was really keen to go to the Glasgow dough school [domestic science college], where they did a dressmaking and pattern-cutting course, she recalls. ldquoBut at school, the teachers were appalled that somebody with brains should aspire to the dough school, so they disallowed it.Her parents were, she thinks, ldquoregretful that I couldnt follow my heart but at the same time pleased that I had the brains to get on further in le, as they saw it. After being steered towards academia, Hunter studied English and drama at Glasgow University, where she became heavily involved in student theatre.Her passion for thread would not be quelled, however, and when she later became the first Scot to get onto the directing course at Bristol Old Vic theatre, she found herself making Shakespearean costumes ndash including ruffs. ldquoI was enthralled by that, really interested in finding out how garments were constructed, she says. After a series of theatre roles she graduated towards the community arts scene, which was then gathering momentum as a way of tackling deprivation through creativity.At , she was running a Salisbury arts centre, helping ex-prisoners and people with mental health problems to re-engage through pottery, printing and creative writing. ldquoIt opened my eyes to how a community could work and create together and how all sorts of people in all sorts of walks of le could share not just the same space but the same achievements.When in , the Peoples March For Jobs set off from Liverpool to highlight unemployment, Hunter ndash now working as an arts development officer in Northampton ndash made a banner to welcome the marchers when they came through the town. ldquoIt was the first banner I ever made and a very scrappy affair ndash just a bit of lining fabric with letters glued on, she recalls.Intrigued by the rich history of banners, she suggested making some with local people in Nottinghamshire after shed been invited by the Mansfield Trades Council to encourage community involvement in May Day events. It was : just as the miners strike was erupting and with the Nottinghamshire workforce bitterly ided over the dispute, Hunter found herself working with miners wives support group members. ldquoI ended up driving them at night through back lanes to picket lines so they wouldnt be stopped by police, she says. ldquoWhen I heard the striking Mansfield miners didnt have banners, I started making some for those groups and that led me to an understanding of how fabric and thread could be used, not just as something that women did quietly at home, but as something that could be much bigger and bolder.Later, as a self-employed arts consultant in London, she realised she wanted not just to work with communities, but to belong to one. Standing outside Covent Garden underground station, she had what she calls her ldquoeureka moment. ldquoI decided to count the number of passers-by who werent aged  to . I think in that  minutes I counted four.For Hunter, that statistic confirmed that central London would never provide the kind of multi-generational, community le she yearned for and she made the snap decision to close up her office andto Scotland.After bundling up her belongings, she rushed to Euston Station but it was almost Christmas, the train was jam-packed and Hunter ndash who was carrying several suitcases and a cat ndash realised she wasnt going to get on.ldquoThen suddenly from inside came the shout of ndash In here, in here! It was a crowd of oil rig workers on their way to Aberdeen, who squeezed me and my cat in. Ive never laughed so much as I did on that journey back to Glasgow.Her jubilation was short-lived. Back living with her mother at the age of , she realised shed gone from being ldquoa well-known consultant leading conferences, wearing nice suits, to basically having nothing. But after securing a pound-a-week Enterprise Allowance, she found a damp but affordable west end flat that was big enough to make banners ndash and began pursuing her dream of setting up ldquoa community enterprise that was about creating jobs for people who had real talent and flair but didnt have the educational qualications to get to art school or even dough school.She called it NeedleWorks and from , the organisation grew into a successful operation, employing eight people and engaging erse cultures, age groups and communities in producing banners, wall-hangings and a witty, Glasgow-themed fashion collection.Not everyone got it. Hunter lost count of the times shed be working with a group of women on an intricate piece of community embroidery, only for some male joker to stop at the table and quip: ldquoIve got some trousers that need taking up, or ldquoCan you sew on a button on my jacket Beyond the cynical fringe, however, textile-based arts were enjoying a renaissance. Impressed by a NeedleWorks banner project hed witnessed in Glasgows east end, the citys director of museums, Julian Spalding, asked Hunterto help create a ldquoBayeux tapestry of Glasgow le during its upcoming year as European City of Culture, .Taking up the challenge, Needleworks engaged more than  Glaswegians in a series of workshops held in Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum. The first ever workshop provoked some curious reactions: ldquoWhat time does the jumble sale begin " asked an elderly couple after spotting a table strewn with bits of cloth. But under the design stewardship of textile artist Malcolm Lochhead, those  peoples efforts were stitched together to create a dozen, ft-high banners, each celebrating an aspect of Clydeside le. Shipyards and tenements, Hampden Park and the Barras, street buskers and pantomime dameshellip all were colourfully rendered in a witty work of collective creativity that was named after an old joke about the citys gallus humour: ldquoCome to Glasgow for a laugh, go away in stitches.Keeping Glasgow In Stitches was universally acclaimed as a triumphbut it was also, Hunter now acknowledges, ldquoa huge project to co-ordinate. In , she collapsed with exhaustion.At the time, NeedleWorks were short-staffed and Hunter was working all hours to complete commissions. During one all-nighter, she phoned her sister and said simply: ldquoI cant do this any more.ldquoMy sister said, Im coming in a taxi, well take everything youre working on back to the workshop and then you are coming home with me. So I went to hers and just slept and slept.After rest, recuperation and contemplation, she decided it was time to voluntarily liquidate NeedleWorks. Another community business agreed to take on two of the staff, some went freelance and Hunter ndash who was about to get married ndash was ready to explore ldquopastures new.Now living in Stirlingshire, she has since gone on to raise a family and spearhead several high-profile community-based textile initiatives. Just last year, for example, she co-ordinated a series of womens banner-making workshops ahead of the June  Edinburgh Processions march, which payed tribute to the Scottish women who fought for the right to vote. The suffragettes themselves, says Hunter, were famous for subverting the domestic craft of needlework to create beautul banners, partly as a rebuke towards those who derided their campaign as ldquounwomanly.Many of their banners ndash like those created in the Processions workshops a century later ndash were works of art. Are we finally beginning to appreciate this long-undervalued discipline ldquoI think we are, says Hunter. ldquoIts interesting that in the age of mass production, the appeal of the homemade has become stronger and stronger. She believes the success of websites like Etsy proves people still value products that express iniduality and identity and that the popularity of knitting and sewing circles like StitchNBitch confirms we still need face-to-face contact, even in the social media age.What about men  As Hunters book makes clear, they too were victims of the  Education Act, which made sewing lessons compulsory for girls but not boys, thus not only channelling female pupils towards domesticity, but robbing their male counterparts of the chance to learn valuable skills.Are things improving  Role models like Glasgow textile artist Malcolm Lochhead and celebrity embroiderer Jamie Chalmersare helping to change attitudes, believes Hunter, but with needlework no longer routinely taught in schools, she thinks both genders are missing out. ldquoChildren ndash and particularly boys ndash love sewing and I think its totally delicious to watch a seven-year-old boy picking up needles and threads for the first time, loving what happens when you push that needle through the cloth and the patterns it makes.Should sewing be reinstated on the curriculum  Hunter herself seems to have been traumatised by her school needlework teacher, who would ldquotut-tut sorrowfully over her failure to master theldquoghastly regulation sewing machines. But she does think ldquocreativity in all its forms should be there at a much higher level ndash be it dance, drama, music, needlework, all these things should be equal to academic subjects.Threads Of Le, which Hunter researched with the help of a Creative Scotland grant, aims to change the way we think about sewing, by demonstrating the crucial role it has played in human culture and history. Its a wonderful book and Hunter is already planning her second, about Mary Queen of Scots and her textiles. That inveterate embroiderer ndash who confounded her jailers by embellishing her clothes with symbols that declared her royal birthright ndash features prominently in Threads Of Le.But, hints the author, there is much more of this story to tell. In Hunters deft hands, it cant help but be enthralling.Threads Of Le: A History Of The World Through The Eye Of A Needle, is published by Sceptre, pound

title: brexit-shows-there-would-be-negative-impact-if-scotland-left-uk
story: Professor John McLaren for the Scottish Trends website said: ldquoThe Brexit-related arguments that the break-up of an economic and customs union will result in a negative impact on future economic growth - due to increased tarf and non-tarf barriers - are also valid in the case of Scottish independence from the UK economic union.ldquoHowever, the degree to which this impact might be greater or lesser than for Brexit remains a matter for debate, he explained.Prof McLaren said it was ldquowidely accepted that Scotland would be deprived of a net transfer, in the region of pound billion, from the rest of the UK in the event of independence.This, he argued, was in contrast to the UK leaving the EU, where the impact was likely to be ldquosmall but positive, although this would be negative once longer term, slower growth impacts were considered.Prof McLaren, former UK Treasury economist, who lectures on public policy at Glasgow Universityrsquos Business School, also suggested that the Brexit debate showed thatScotland voted to become independent, then this was likely to lead to a ldquoplethora of options for what independence might actually mean.He explained: ldquoThis ranges from an old-style nation-state to remaining in some form of political and economic union with both the EU and the UK.ldquoA bespoke arrangement with both bodies seems likely to result in the most advantageous - or least detrimental - outcome in economic terms.This, Prof McLaren, argued this might involve an independent Scotland having membership of the European Economic Area similar to Norway or being part of a British economic union, similar in form to the current EU in terms of being an area of shared political sovereignty and economic co-operation amongst its member nation states.ldquoSuch a lsquoBritish Union might allow for the use of sterling, no trade barriers and some degree of continuing fiscal transfer, he suggested.The academic said that while, as with Brexit, the first economic impact of such changes to the political and economic landscape around a second referendum might have little influence on the electorate, the second fiscal impact was more likely to affect, negatively, voting intentions.This, he suggested, in turn might make it more likely that an ldquoalternative form of independence was proposed which helped ameliorate some of these impacts.Prof McLaren said: ldquoThe UK Parliamentrsquos Brexit discussions have provided a useful insight into how the next Scottish referendum may pan out.ldquoThe range of possible Brexit outcomes highlights how independence is not an agreed, single, end-point but will inevitably involve a prolonged process of negotiations with both the EU and the UK.ldquoThis leads to a much more complicated landscape for future arrangements than was perceived at the time of the first independence referendum.He added: ldquoThe acknowledged loss of a net transfer of public funds from the UK to Scotland may also lead to greater latitude with respect to what any future political and economic relationships may look like."Willie Rennie, the leader of the Scottish Liberal Democrats, said: ldquoThis report should make clear to the Nationalists that independence would only worsen the economic chaos of Brexit.ldquoStraight away, independence would mean almost poundbn per year less for public services. A lower rate of economic growth will further eat away at cash for the NHS and education.ldquoRather than stomp their feet, the SNP should face the facts: breaking up is hard to do, he added.

title: scots-firms-cash-in-on-tourism-boom-that-is-full-of-eastern-promise
story: From ensuring hot water and boiled rice is served at mealtimes to scrapping creamy dishes from the menu ndash the subtle nuances of Chinese customs, tastes and superstitions is now vital for Scottish businesses hoping to cash in on a Far East tourism boom.Now hospitality, tourism and retail businesses across Scotland are set to receive priceless help in grasping the cultural challenges presented by soaring numbers of Chinese visitors, in the hope that the nation can capture a lucrative and growing new tourism market.A ground-breaking programme originally launched in Edinburgh to prepare for Chinese sightseers, is now being expanded to help other Scottish cities roll out the red carpet.According to Scottish Enterprise, which is adapting Edinburghrsquos successful China Ready initiative for other locations starting with Greater Glasgow, evidence shows ldquothe China syndrome is seeping well beyond the capital.ldquoGlasgow businesses are saying they are starting to see incremental growth month-on-month from Chinese visitors and students coming to study, says Sallyann Tindall, senior tourism project manager at Scottish Enterprise, adding that Dundee is also witnessing signicant rise.ldquoTherersquos a real appetite among businesses to grow their Chinese market. Edinburghrsquos China Ready initiative, designed two years ago to provide a foundation in Chinese culture and customs for the cityrsquos frontline tourism sector, has already seen many businesses introduce Chinese-friendly contactless payment systems and conquer welcoming Mandarin phrases.As well as establishing a signicant presence on Chinese social media channels, the Edinburgh initiative has offered hotels, restaurants and retailers tips on culture ndash such as paying particular respect towards the senior travellers in a Chinese party and providing complimentary toothbrushes in bedrooms.Similar initiatives, including restaurant menu cards written in Mandarin, are planned for Glasgow.Rob Lang, the Edinburgh Airport marketing executive and chairman of Edinburgh Tourist Action Group, which designed the China Ready initiative, says: ldquoItrsquos about getting the basics right and small things that make a big dference. We want to make sure we donrsquot do anything to embarrass anyone. Something as simple as a Mandarin language map thatrsquos easily available so tourists can walk about the city and understand what they are seeing, is important.A key area of focus for Edinburghrsquos China Ready initiative has been establishing a presence on Chinese social media s, Weibo and WeChat. A Mandarin-speaker now regularly updates ldquoEdinburgh Official posts, while Chinese social media influencers and bloggers have been invited to sample Edinburgh hospitality.To further boost its bid to be regarded as the UKrsquos friendliest destination for Chinese visitors, the cityrsquos first full-scale Chinese New Year Festival will get under way today, involving a major cultural programme of arts and entertainment.Several of the cityrsquos landmark buildings, including Edinburgh Castle, the Balmoral Hotel,Camera Obscura and Harvey Nichols, will be bathed in red light throughout, while Chinese-themed events will be held at venues including the Usher Hall.At the same time, Glasgowrsquos Princes Square is preparing to mark the Chinese New Year with Mandarin language signs, and events centred on a large Chinese-style pagoda in its courtyard. Red envelopes ndash a Chinese New Year tradition ndash are to be distributed by retailers.The moves are designed to beef up Scotsrsquo understanding of Chinese culture and are in response to tourism figures that show an almost six-fold increase in visitors since . In , there were , Chinese visitors ndash a rise of  per cent on the previous year ndash who spent a total ofpound million. In the same year, Edinburgh Castle alone recorded , visitors who listed their point of origin as China.Itrsquos expected the figures for  will be signicantly higher following the launch of direct flights between Edinburgh and Beijing last summer. UK flight forecast figures for December  to February  currently predict a  per cent rise in Chinese visitors.According to VisitScotland, Edinburgh is the second most visited city in the UK by Chinese tourists, bettered only by London.Malcolm Roughead, chief executive of VisitScotland, says: ldquoChina has huge tourism potential for Scotland, with indications that it will grow further in the coming years.

title: the-elephant-in-the-park-never-forgets-the-little-ones-lost-in-time
story: That, says Dorothy Maitland, who battled for years to find out what happened to her dead baby daughter Kaelenrsquos ashes only to find herself unravelling a scandal that affected at least  other Edinburgh babies, is part of its charm.ldquoItrsquos perfect, she says, finally seeing it for the first time in its position at the west end of the Gardens close to the Ross Bandstand, and overshadowed by the Castle.ldquoIt seems to ooze comfort and love. You can stop, look and have your thoughts, and it doesnrsquot have to be too obvious that yoursquore grieving. Irsquom hoping that a lot of people will see it as a way of moving forward.Families affected by the cityrsquos Mortonhall Crematorium baby ashes scandal will have their first chance to see Kelpiesrsquo creator Andy Scottrsquos pound, baby elephant sculpture today when the two-metre tall bronze is formally unveiled.Regardless of the passing of the years and the conclusion of ious probing inquiries into what happened to their childrenrsquos final remains, it is expected to be a deeply poignant and moving ceremony.For Ms Maitland, whose baby Kaelen died in her arms at just nine days old after being born a month early with a heart disorder, the unveiling will be bitter-sweet.ldquoKaelen would have been  years old, she says. ldquoShe is always with me. Kaelen is very much a part of our family and she always will be.It emerged in  that the ashes of at least  babies cremated at Mortonhall Crematorium had been buried in secret.The policy had continued for more than four decades, during which time hundreds of grieving parents ndash many of whom had sought their babiesrsquo ashes for comfort or perhaps to create their own personal memorial ndash were systematically told by staff and funeral directors that none were available after cremation.The babyrsquos ashes were instead buried at secret locations in the crematorium grounds. The baby elephant is the cityrsquos second memorial to the Mortonhall babies. A pound, walled garden opened in  within the grounds of crematorium, close to where many of the babiesrsquo ashes are believed to be buried.However, the sculpture was planned for the heart of the capital to provide a focal point for families too distressed toto Mortonhall.Mr Scott said: ldquoIt was quite daunting to take on because of the emotions and terrible loss that the parents suffered. It wasnrsquot a project I took on lightly.ldquoI wanted to do something that would capture the imagination. I wanted something like a little lost toy that a child might have left behind, with a feeling of sadness and loss. The passer-by might look at it as a nice sculpture, but it has a more pertinent and intimate meaning for the parents. It is embossed with forget-me-nots, which gives extra meaning. And elephants never forget.The Edinburgh sculpture, dubbed Lulla-Bye and cast at the cityrsquos Powderhall Bronze, is part of a council action plan in response to  recommendations made by former Lord Advocate Dame Elish Angiolini, who led the Edinburgh inquiry into the scandal. The discovery of the Mortonhall scandal led to a string of similar practices being uncovered in other locations, including Glasgow and Aberdeen. A nationwide investigation was later carried out by the Infant Cremation Commissionndash chaired by Lord Bonomy on behalf of the Scottish Government.It led to the passing in  of The Burial and Cremation Scotland Bill, which sets out a legal definition of ashes and requires authorities to keep details of burials and cremations indefinitely. Local authorities were also instructed to provide suitable memorials for families to access.In Glasgow, the council is working with parents to establish the cityrsquos memorial near Glasgow Cathedral. The parents of any child cremated at either Daldowie or Linn, prior to March , can choose to have their childrsquos name included in the memorial. Meanwhile, work started last month on a memorial garden in Aberdeenrsquos Hazlehead Park which will also feature a sculpture.Ms Maitland adds: ldquoI see it as a way of moving forward, and a memorial for every baby that has died, not just for Mortonhall families, but anyone who has lost a baby will find enormous comfort from visiting here. The elephant is so appropriate, elephants care for their young and event their young that have died, they are very protective. Itrsquos a great choice.

title: analysis-eu-can-just-say-non-to-may-and-wait-for-mps-to-vote-for-article-50-extension
story: Time is zipping by just  days to go until Britain is due to leave the Brussels bloc. In the coming week officials and ministers will continue the big schmooze by having more tea and talks with those nice Labour MPs and trade union chiefs on issues like workersrsquo rights.If, by some miracle, the Prime Minister persuades the EU to perform a screeching U-turn and agree a change on the backstop, then when she s home victorious, it could be she will still have to rely on some or all of those  Labour rebels, who defied Jeremy Corbyn this week, to squeeze Plan B through the Commons probably after writing out promissory cheques for several Leave constituencies.Yet as the Brexit clock ticks down, it is becoming increasingly clear it is less likely Britain will leave on March . Why so  A number of reasons.The talk of using a technological solution to the backstop riddle was itself rubbished by Mrs May only a few months ago. No one sincerely believes it will happen any time soon.At Westminster, some  of the  Statutory Instruments required for Brexit still have to be passed and there are less than eight weeks to go.No  blithely insisted it was always envisaged the parliamentary process would be accelerated as exit day approached but, in Star Trek parlance, this would need Warp Factor  to get everything through on time. Scrapping the February recess seems a desperately late move and may ultimately have little effect.The fact each day a Cabinet minister raises the prospect of putting back March  -only for a few weeks to allow legislation to be passed in the event of a new deal being agreed - appears to be a softening-up exercise for when it happens but for a much longer period.From all the noises on the continent - Juncker, Tusk, Varadkar, Merkel, Macron, etc - it seems hard to disagree with the SNP leader Ian Blackford that Mrs May has a ldquocat in hellrsquos chance of getting the backstop scrapped.All the EU chiefs have to do is sit on their hands and wait for the Valentinersquos Day vote in the Commons, knowing an amendment to extend Article  will be tabled and pushed through with the help of Cabinet ministers, who, by then, may be ex-Cabinet ministers.The soundbite that jumped out this week was when Andrea Leadsom, the Commons Leader, proudly declared: ldquoWe are under pressure but it is all very much under control and we do expect to achieve what we need to do by March .Self-deception is a long-standing Westminster affliction.

title: nicola-sturgeon-embarks-on-five-day-tour-of-usa-and-canada
story: The First Minister will embark on whistle-stop tour of Washington DC, New York, New Jersey, Ottawa and Toronto over five days.It comes as new figures show the US remains Scotlandrsquos top export destination, with an estimated pound. billion of exports in  ndash up by . per cent from the previous year.However, Ms Sturgeonrsquos visit also means she will avoid being quizzed on the revised Scottish Budget at First Ministerrsquos Questions on Thursday.MSPs will now not be given the chance to question her until February , after the Scottish Parliamentrsquos recess.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoScotland has a longstanding relationship with North America across family, friendship, culture and business.ldquoThe latest figures released just this week show how important our trade relationship with North America is for our economy.ldquoThis visit will build on the existing links between our countries and provide new opportunities for us to work together and learn from each otherrsquos expertise in areas including climate change, renewables and gender equality.ldquoWith the shadow of Brexit hanging over our economy, it is more important now than ever to reassure businesses that Scotland is an open and welcoming country and an attractive place to invest in, visit and live.Her engagements include an address at Georgetown University to discuss Brexit, and the launch of the Scotland is Now campaign in Canada.But officials said there are no plans to meet President Donald Trump, who is scheduled to give the State of the Union address on Tuesday.Further potential political meetings are still being finalised.Ms Sturgeon last visited the US in , when she gave a speech at Stanford University and met Governor of Calornia Jerry Brown to discuss climate change.Her trip to Canada, which continues to be a top  export destination for Scotland, will be the first visit by a First Minister in more than ten years.

title: no-10-tells-brussels-completely-unacceptable-to-describe-gibraltar-as-a-uk-colony
story: The language was used in a European Council document setting out plans for visa-free travel for Britons after Brexit, which noted the "controversy between Spain and the UK" over the sovereignty of the Rock. A footnote stated: ldquoGibraltar is a colony of the British Crown.Fears have been raised that Theresa Mayrsquos bid to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement to scrap the Irish backstop could tempt Madrid to renew the row over its claim to Gibraltar.Downing Street was quick to respond to the ldquocolony reference with the Prime Ministerrsquos spokesman insisting: "It is completely unacceptable to describe Gibraltar in this way."Gibraltar is a full part of the UK family. This will not change due to our exit from the EU," he said.Fabian Picardo, Gibraltars Chief Minister, pointed the finger at Madrid, accusing it of trying to "bully" the British Overseas Territory by demanding the contentious description in the draft document."No one will be surprised to hear the Spanish Government making provocative statements in respect of Gibraltar. The , people of Gibraltar are used to the constant attempts by successive Spanish governments to bully us in every possible way."This is no dferent to the sort of abuse we have had from former Spanish administration," he added.In November, a row with Pedro Sanchez, the Spanish premier, over the Rock almost derailed efforts to agree the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement between the Prime Minister and the EU.It was only resolved after a clarication about the legal position and emergency talks involving Mr Sanchez, Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission President, and Donald Tusk, the European Council President.Spain ceded Gibraltar to Britain in perpetuity in the  Treaty of Utrecht.In June  in a referendum on the Rock,  per cent of those taking part voted to stay part of the UK turnout was  per cent.In other developments:*Dominic Raab, the former Brexit Secretary, questioned whether David Lidington, the PMrsquos de facto deputy, who backed Remain in the  EU referendum, had the ldquokind of Brexiteer credentials to be part of Mrs Mayrsquos enhanced Brexit negotiating team.*John Bercow, the Commons Speaker, insisted in an interview with US TV channel CNN, that he was neutral on Brexit and only wanted to give voice to "minority or dissident" in the Commons. He expressed "concern" that no resolution had been reached on Brexit but stressed: "It isnrsquot something the Speaker can determine."*Nick Boles, the former Conservative minister, who was the co-sponsor of the unsuccessful Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment to extend the Article  process, described the forthcoming second meaningful vote on Brexit as the "last chance saloon" to prevent a no-deal outcome.*DUP leader Arlene Foster urged the EU to ldquoface up to reality" on the backstop, saying: "The blockage to getting a deal is the backstop therefore, there must be sensible engagement and a pragmatic approach.*No  brushed off a suggestion from Helen McEntee, Irelandrsquos Europe Minister, that the UK bid to extend Article  would ldquobe approvedrequested. The PMs spokesman insisted: "We have not requested an extension and we will be leaving on March ."*Simon Coveney, Irelandrsquos Deputy PM, is preparing to visit America to talk, among other things, about Brexit, prompting speculation he will seek support from Washington for its position on the backstop. When asked about the prospect, No  said the Tanaistersquos travel plans were a "matter for Mr Coveney".*A new Brexit party backed by Nigel Farage, the former Ukip leader, has received pledges worth more than pound million and is said to be lining up candidates to fight a snap General Election.

title: tom-gordon-green-deal-shows-inadequacy-of-other-parties-on-budget
story: Did they feel pride over the sht their MSPs put in during talks with Finance Secretary Derek Mackay Did they cheer and punch the air at a deal that met their local needs Did they applaud the tough but necessary compromises that brought a bit more money to communities in these uncertain times Or did they just gawp and think, Where the hell were my lot Since the draft budget for   was published in mid-December, all the Holyrood opposition parties have spoken to Mr Mackay about a deal. But all the Unionist ones failed to engage seriously, asking the SNP for the eye-wateringly expensive, or the eye-rollingly stupid, like abandoning independence.Labour, who run or help run  of our  local authorities, got their councillors nothing. The Tories, who run seven authorities, got their councillors nothing. And the LibDems, who run six authorities, got - you guessed it - nothing.The handful of Green councillors elected two years ago got something very dferent. Irsquom not saying everyone was happy - the party seems obliged to disagree with itself - but they would at least have seen their six MSPs in the thick of it.It was not an easy process. During the final to-ing and fro-ing over numbers and commitments, many Green MSPs seemed genuinely pained, and not just by Ross Greerrsquos bon mots on Winston Churchill.Besides the fear of letting their side down by settling too cheaply, there was the weight of being the only non-government party still involved. The others had simply quit the field. The Greens felt thatthey didnrsquot strike a deal, there could be chaos. How would the government react  Would there be an election on top of Brexit  Who would that help There was a lot of resentment towards the other parties. Instead of feeling duty-bound to participate, there was tribal intransigence.As Green co-convener Patrick Harvie said on Thursday, the other parties seemed to have drawn precisely the wrong lesson from the Brexit dys at Westminster and thought, Letrsquos have some of that.ldquoI can respect anyone who busts a gut to achieve a change, is unable to, and then votes against the budget - but not even to try  he said.ldquoOthers seem to think that engineering a crisis would be the best outcomehellip chaos for the sake of chaos is not what Scotland needs. Itrsquos a very good point.Of course, the other parties were not entirely indferent. Away from Holyrood, their councillors were trying to influence Mr Mackay through the council group Cosla, which backed the Green demands for more money and more powers. It was noteworthy that in Coslarsquos response to the budget, both President Allison Evisonand resources spokesperson Gail Macgregorthanked the Greens.But at Holyrood, MSPs were cynical and complacent, preferring to posture rather than deliver. Mr Harviersquos arguments failed to move them, so how about self-interest If you want to be the government, you have to look the part. Slacking off and bitching from the back of the class do not look the part.Like Mr Harvie says, Labour and the Tories donrsquot have to vote for an SNP budget at the end of the day, but at least engage. See it as training. Work that intellectual muscle. You canrsquot go into the  election looking like lightweights and hope the SNP will conveniently lose.The Tories seem to get it. They had no alternative budget, but there was less knockabout than usual from Murdo Fraser. He was also sharp on the numbers. Like Finance Committee convener Bruce Crawford, he highlighted a scary, technical issue over income tax that could start to bite in  .Labour were an embarrassment. With the leadership doing next to nothing, it emerged frontbencher Alex Rowley had sent his personal budget plan to Mr Mackay. When the freelancing operation was discovered, Labour HQ hauled him in, shut him up, and refused to let him speak in Thursdayrsquos debate.Instead that honour went to James Kelly, whose performance, God willing, is unlikely to be surpassed for the rest of the year.It wasnrsquot just the atrocious delivery , it was the atrocious content. He railed against councils cuts, but would not say how to avoid them. He was then stumped when asked what Labour had got out of the last three budgets.He does not look like a future finance secretary, nor help Labour look like a government in waiting.ldquoWe should just send a clip of him round all the business leaders, one senior SNP source said later, half-joking that would neutralise the Labour threat at the next election.The current budget approach isnrsquot helping the SNPrsquos rivals. Itrsquos a bad habit. If they donrsquot break it,they donrsquot take more responsibility and show more intellectual heft, they shouldnrsquot expect the respect of voters. MSPs ing empty-handed to council colleagues canrsquot help party management either.There will soon be cross-party talks on replacing council tax and reforming local government finance. The people who pay their salaries deserve more from MSPs than lazy partisanship in that exercise.Holyroodrsquos new powers are also creating new risks to the budget, like that income tax worry I mentioned. A thoughtful, collective approach to them is needed. MSPs should step up. As Mr Crawford said: ldquoThese are challenging times indeed, and we must rise to the challenges on behalf of the Scottish people.

title: scotlands-biggest-council-union-overwhelmingly-accepts-pay-deal
story: Unison, which had recommended accepting the offer, said % of members who responded to a consultative ballot voted to take the deal.It is worth an extra .% to , council workers in the current financial year, backdated to April , and % in both   and  .It also means the Scottish living wage will rise at the same amount in local government, ensuring more money for lower paid council staff.The GMB union has also recommended acceptance of the offer - against after Unite recommended rejection as the offer did not include a lsquotrigger clausersquo allowing it to be reopenedBrexit caused inflation to spike.Unite also complained that it would not restore its membersrsquo pay to the real-terms levels of  years ago.Johanna Baxter, the head of local government for Unison in Scotland, said: ldquoThis is a great outcome, delivered as a direct result of the campaigning activity and political lobbying efforts of Unison members up and down the country.ldquoThe cost of living increases meet current and projected levels of RPI-inflation and we have secured commitments to fully consolidate the living wage and maintain parity across the local government workforce.ldquoOur members have been waiting on a pay increase for over a year now so look forward to receiving their increase soon.Mark Ferguson, chair of Unisonrsquos local government committee in Scotland, added: ldquoUnison has campaigned hard to get the best deal we can for local government workers.ldquoWhile the offer does not make up for the many years of austerity, the offer, and particularly the commitment to consolidate the Living Wage, provides important safeguards for our lowest paid members.ldquoWe will work to ensure this is properly delivered and local government workers receive backdated money in their pay packets in coming months.Councillor Gail Macgregor, resources spokesperson of the council umbrella group Cosla, which made the offer, said: ldquoThis is a result of the determination on both sides to reach an agreement. Cosla will need to dig a bit deeperwe are to avoid industrial action.A ballot of Unite craft members in councils, such as electricians and joiners, ends on Monday.The union also warned SNP-Green plans in the budget for a new workplace parking levy could further undermine public sector pay.

title: finding-crying-newborn-baby-in-shopping-bag-was-shocking-dog-walker-says

title: brexit-policing-costs-in-scotland-should-be-met-by-treasury-say-snp
story: Chief constable Iain Livingstone has said ldquoreasonable worst-case scenario planning for the UK leaving the EU means  of his officers being deployed on Brexit duty.He has brought forward recruitment of  officers and ditched plans to cut numbers by  ndash costing a possible pound million ndash to have sufficient strength to deal with possible public disorder and disruption at ports following the UKrsquos exit from the bloc.The SNP have called on the Treasury to pay out, pointing out Scotland voted by % to % to remain in the EU.SNP MSP Rona Mackay, deputy convener of the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Justice Committee, said: ldquoThe reality of the Brexit situation we face is becoming increasingly apparent ndash with Scotlandrsquos chief constable clear in his professional assessment of what extra pressures will fall upon Police Scotland.ldquoItrsquos important that hersquos planning for the worst-case scenario since, regrettably, thatrsquos the brink that the Tories seem to be dragging us closer towards.ldquoThe risk of disorder, disruption at ports and airports, and the need for Scottish police officers to be redeployed to help forces where, are outcomes becoming all too possible in the event of a no-deal.She added: ldquoBut this is not a mess of Scotlandrsquos making. We voted Remain, we voted for stability and security in Europe and itrsquos a situation created by the Tory government against our express will.ldquoOn that basis, itrsquos only fair that the Treasury foots the bill for all contingency costs incurred by Police Scotland.ldquoPolice forces in the rest of the UK have had extra funding in these circumstances and Scotland should be treated no dferently.ldquoUltimately, the vital work Police Scotland does to keep our communities safe should not be jeopardised by the additional pressures of a Tory Brexit, which we have stood firmly against at every turn.Earlier this week, Mr Livingston called for the necessary contingency funding to be made available, pointing out the UK Government has given around pound million additional cash to the Police Service of Northern Ireland, as well as money to some forces in England to tackle the issue.He warnedno extra cash is received it could threaten the financial stability of Police Scotland.A UK Government spokeswoman said: ldquoWe are working closely with the Scottish Government on EU exit plans and have so far given them pound million to support Brexit preparations for all scenarios.ldquoIt is for the Scottish Government to decide whether any of this extra funding should be allocated to Police Scotland.

title: bbc-licence-fee-to-rise-by-4-to-15450
story: The Government, which sets the level of the licence fee, announced in  that it would increase in line with inflation for five years from April  .This means the cost of the licence will go up from pound. to pound. from April , the BBC said.The announcement comes as freeTV licences for over-s are being reviewed.The broadcaster has launched a consultation on the issue but warned that thecost of continuing to provide free TV licences for over-s would ldquofundamentally change the BBC.The corporation took over the cost from the Government as part of its charter renewal negotiations.The Government-funded scheme,which provides free TV licences to older viewers, comes to an end in June .Age UK recently claimed that as many as , UK pensioners could be pushed below the poverty linethe free TV licence is scrapped.The BBC said: ldquoThe new licence fee amount equates to just pound. a week or pound. a month, for which the BBC provides nine national TV channels plus regional programming,  national radio stations,  local radio stations plus dedicated Nations radio services, one of the UKrsquos most popular websites, the radio app BBC Sounds, and BBC iPlayer.It added: ldquoProgrammes last year included Strictly Come Dancing, Killing Eve, Bodyguard, Dr Who, Peter Kayrsquos Car Share, David Attenboroughrsquos Dynasties, EastEnders, Match Of The Day, and coverage of Wimbledon and the World Cup.The BBC, which announced a new natural history series with Sir David Attenborough on Thursday night, has faced controversy over the use of personal service companies for its stars and the gender pay gap.Since the furore over talent pay, Zoe Ball has taken over from Chris Evans, who had been one of the BBCrsquos biggest earners, on Radio rsquos Breakfast Show, while Fiona Bruce landed the role of Question Time host.TV Licensing defended plans to spend at least pound. million ofBBC licence fee-payersrsquo money on external PR agencies to promote the annual charge.

title: musicians-education-chiefs-festival-directors-unite-to-call-for-free-music-tuition-for-children-in-scotland
story: On the day that one Scottish council confirmed it is planning to cut musical instrument teaching in its schools, leading figures including Nicola Benedetti and Dame Evelyn Glennie, have spoken out to back free music education.Midlothian Council could become one of the first Scottish local authorities to cut musical instrument tuition in its schools, apart from children who are studying for Higher or National Five exams.The councils plans, described as "shameful" by the leader of the countrys largest teaching union, come only a fortnight after the Scottish Parliaments education committee declared that instrument tuition should remain free.Ms Benedetti, a passionate advocate of music education, said funding for music tuition at councils should be ring-fenced.Larry Flanagan, the general secretary of the EIS, attacked the planned cuts, which come as other councils are planning to raise fees and cut tutors.He said: "Midlothian Councilrsquos decision to axe instrumental music tuition in its schools is a ridiculously short-sighted decision."This penny-pinching move will rob young people in Midlothian of an invaluable opportunity to develop their musical abilities, and deny them the many added benefits that instrumental instruction can offer."Learning music benefits young people in terms of their self-confidence, and in their ability to work both independently or as part of a larger group."It is a bitter irony that, shortly after the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Education Committee has recommended that instrumental music tuition should be provided free by all local authorities, the response of Midlothian Council is to scrap music tuition altogether."Midlothian Council must reconsider this shameful decision as a matter of urgency."Ms Benedetti, who launched her own educational music Foundation last week, said there was a clear conflict between "the national rhetoric and messaging and what the councils actually feel they can implement, and also the local councils value and belief systems: there is quite clearly a disconnect."The award winning musician, who is toto Scotland to perform a series of concerts with the RSNO next week, added: "Everyone who understands the importance of maintaining music in schools, we have to pull together and sing from the same hymn sheet."The ultimate goal would be to have funds ring-fenced, on a national level, where these decisions on a council level cannot be made."Youd be hard pushed to find people who dont believe, within music education, that the situation is worse than it has been in many peoples letime."The leader of Midlothian Council, Derek Milligan, said he was "devastated" by the prospect of cutting instrument lessons.He added: "If councillors decided to save instrumental tuition, it just means we have to find the money by stopping something ."Councillors will consider the savings, put forward by council officers, at a council meeting on  December.Cllr Millgan added: ldquoIf councillors decide to save instrumental tuition, it just means we have to find the money by stopping something ."So while we are as devastated as parents and pupils about having to consider such a drastic cut to this service, this needs to be seen in the context of preserving the core educational and care services Midlothian residents depend on.Pupils studying for Higher and Advanced Higher music will continue to receive instrumental music tuition free of charge.Children will also still get music in schools as part of the normal curriculum.However, there will no longer be the opportunity to pay for extra lessons to learn a musical instrument.

title: letters-gers-shows-up-westminsters-lack-of-investment-outside-the-london-bubble
story: GERS charges Scotland pound. billion a year as a share of interest payments on UKs national debt but makes no allowance for a share of the UKs worldwide assets. Alsoa Scottish government were to tax oil companies at the Norwegian level or the UK  level it would produce pound billion a year in revenues.GERS is a testament to Westminsters lack of investment outside the London bubble and there is no reason why Scotland cant emulate the success of Denmark and other small northern European countries, many of whom have far fewer natural resources.What is undeniable is that as part of the UK, Scotland is currently under-performing, and there is little reason to doubt that this will continue to be the case unless change is made. No less an authority than former Treasury Minister Lord Jim OrsquoNeill described Britainrsquos woeful performance on income per head, productivity and regional inequality as ldquobog standard stats that should surprise no one.Fraser Grant,Warrender Park Road, Edinburgh.ALEX Gallagher contends that the Sustainable Growth Commissionldquoconfirms, the [pound billion] gap [identied by GERS] exists. It doesnrsquot. Rather it suggests thatother than UK Government accounting conventions are used, for instance UN or Eurostat national accounts conventions, the GERS outcome would be dferent. Moreover, the ldquolack of discrete data on Scotland ndash for instance  of the  revenue headings are estimates ndash leads to the conclusion that the ldquoGERS analysis can only be an estimate of Scotlandrsquos position that reflects the current constitutional situation. Those three words again, but vital to understanding how GERS can be used.However, given his reference to this report, I am astonished he goes on to assert it ldquoconfirms the pound billion gap ... ldquowill continue to existwe break up the UK, when its  pages concern how an independent Scotland might ldquomove away from the unsustainable levels of deficit and debt created by UK management toward a sustainable position.Moreover, it does not argue it would take  years to replace the ldquoUnion idend, but that it would take between five and  years to put our finances on a ldquosustainable footing, as ldquocontinuing on the current UK model is unlikely to produce better outcomes than those seen at present.The key, as the report sets out, is expanding the Scottish economy so that spending in the public sector becomes, relative to a larger productive sector, a smaller proportion. However, Westminster policy has been inappropriate, as Scotland, as Margaret Cuthbert has argued, has been ldquodenied the specic, local policies it needs.With independence this need no longer be true. Scotland could develop and implement more appropriate economic policies, applying the high level of skills of a well-educated population, using our other assets such as world-class universities, an outstanding reputation for premium food and drink products, tourism based on the natural beauty of our country. Scotland is also a world leader in computer games technology, photonics and le sciences. Then there is energy, and not just oil but also the potential of renewables. Beyond economics, per cent of welfare decisions were no longer taken at Westminster, we could systematically address the scourge of poverty and disadvantage, which have grown under the last two Westminster governments.Lastly, Councillor Gallagher challenged me to set out a positive case for independence. Perhaps he would like to consider doing likewise for Scotland remaining in the UK post-Brexit, a policy he himself described as ldquostupidity on stilts, managed by a ldquomalevolent Tory government, opposed by a Labour Party which ldquohas failed to deliver clear leadership on the way forward for the UK.Alasdair Galloway, Silverton Avenue, Dumbarton.I AM not often driven to write about economics and politics as I find that facts do not often change peoples opinions, eventheir opinions are based on hoods, but the letter from Councillor Alex Gallagherdeserves some response, especially when he refers to others "mistakes and misunderstandings".I will not go into the fact that GERS is only a crude estimate of Scotlands economic performance as an economic region of the UK, under UK tax and spend policies and therefore is irrelevant to how its performance would beindependent. Nor will I go into comparing the last two released figures, whereyou work out what Westminster is charging for the retained matters, one cannot help but smell a giant rat. I will not even go into the fact that there are things in the retained matters that an independent Scotland will not have to pay for.I will just correct his figure of pound billion for Scotlands calculated deficit . His figure is out of date. The last given GERS deficit figure was poundbn, not . A clear mistake.Ian Cope, Strathblane Gardens, Glasgow.IT iswith great dismay that I note that the debate in the Scottish Parliament on the budget was marred by the infantile actions and behaviour of the members of the Scottish Government Sturgeon breaks her promises as council tax to rise", The Herald, February . There seems to be great delight from senior members of the Government in participating in gestures and actions against the opposition in order to attempt to humiliate them. The fact that one of the senior members of the government fell off her seat during this says it all.This seems to be a consistent theme and only leads to the diminution of the proceedings of the parliament and gives credence to Billy Connollys description of "a wee pretendy parliament". The First Minister seems to delight in encouraging this, and Ive no doubt thatshe took notice of this letter the response would be "I take no lessons from xxxx". Its extremely sad and disheartening to witness this behaviour from what are supposed to be our senior politicians. Please wake up and try and behave as the people of Scotland would wish.Doug Eadie,Glebe Gardens, Alexandria.Read more: Scottish grandees to be quizzed on relations between London and Edinburgh

title: pushing-brexit-past-march-acceptable-to-rees-mogg-but-only-to-finalise-laws
story: The leading Brexiteer said a brief extension to the Article  period, which is currently due to end on March , ldquois not impossibleneeded for Parliament to complete scrutiny of a withdrawal agreement.However, Mr Rees-Mogg insisted that such a delay must not be used for further ldquovacuous negotiations with Brussels.The chairman of the European Research Group of Leave-supporting Tories indicated his support for a limited delay after Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned extra time would be needed to pass lawsMPs approve a deal at the eleventh hour.Earlier this week Theresa May secured Parliamentrsquos backing to go back to Brussels in hope of hammering out a fresh agreement that does not include the Irish border backstop ndash which is unacceptable to the DUP and Brexiteer Tories ndash and which will command a majority in the Commons.The Prime Minister is due to report back to Parliament on her negotiations with the EU on February , with a further series of votes by MPs expected the following day.Wrangling in the Commons has seen backbench MPs put forward a range of alternative plans to find a way out of the morass.They include amending legislation to delay Britainrsquos scheduled departure from the EU and avoid a no-deal Brexit which some consider would be damaging.ldquoAttempts to postpone the date of departure from the European Union beyond March  are little more than ploys to keep the United Kingdom as a member state in spite of the referendum and subsequent Acts of Parliament, Mr Rees-Mogg said.However he accepted that, with  days left till Brexit day, the timetable is ldquotight anda deal is struck and laws of such magnitude will demand proper scrutiny.ldquoThus,the agreement were made but a little parliamentary time were needed, as long as the second reading had taken place a short extension is not impossible, he said.ldquoEqually, to delay for the purpose of vacuous discussions would be solely to thwart Brexit. It must not be for that purpose and should be opposednegotiations are incomplete.Mr Rees-Mogg has backed the so-called Malthouse Compromise, drawn up by MPs from the Toriesrsquo Remain and Leave wings, as a means of getting a deal through Parliament.This would see the backstop removed and replaced with a free trade agreement that would avoid the need for a hard border in Ireland.Good news, the Prime Minister will seek to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement. pic HuIAPqKmdash Jacob Rees-MoggJanuary , Eurosceptics would also agree that the implementation would last for an extra year, Mr Rees-Mogg said.He added thatthe EU rejects the plan then Britain would leave without a deal, but with a ldquopurchased implementation period that would give until  for the UK and EU to either begin trading on World Trade Organisationrules or strike a new agreement.Reports have suggested Mrs May could face a wave of resignations by pro-Remain ministersshe does not rule out a no-deal Brexit when she s to Westminster from Brussels in a fortnightrsquos time.In an interview with the Financial Times published on Saturday, Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd said she felt no-deal would be a ldquobad outcome and I feel we are getting too close to it.ldquoIrsquom concerned it could happen by mistake. The Government and all MPs have a responsibility to try to stop that, she said.A range of dire predictions have been made about the potential consequences of Britain crashing out of the EU without a deal next month.On Saturdayreported that Environment Agency officials have raised concerns internally over the potential for a backlog of wasteexport licences become void overnight on March .Mary Creagh, chairwoman of the Commons Environmental Audit Committee, told the paper: ldquoThe UKrsquos waste and recycling system is already fragile but these shocking emails show it will grind to a haltcustoms checks and WTO tarfs prevent the export of millions of tonnes of waste.

title: jo-coxs-widower-accuses-jeremy-corbyn-of-defending-a-dictator-over-venezuela-views
story: Brendan Cox, a former chief strategist at Save the Children, spoke out after the opposition leader attacked ldquooutside interference in the socialist South American country.Mr Cox attacked the leadership of the countryrsquos president, Nicolas Maduro, which has left the country in the grip of a social and economic collapse that has triggered a humanitarian crisis.The future of Venezuela has been taken out of the hands of Venezuelans by an increasingly corrupt and totalitarian state. By all means call for dialogue butyou donrsquot strongly condemn the subjugation of democracy it sounds like you are defending a dictator. https:t.co sYtUEpXFxlmdash Brendan CoxFebruary , Writing on Twitter on Saturday, Mr Cox said: ldquoThe future of Venezuela has been taken out of the hands of Venezuelans by an increasingly corrupt and totalitarian state.ldquoBy all means call for dialogue butyou donrsquot strongly condemn the subjugation of democracy it sounds like you are defending a dictator.Mr Corbyn on Friday criticised Jeremy Hunt, saying the Foreign Secretary was ldquowrong to demand sanctions against the Maduro regime.Mr Hunt spoke on Wednesday to Juan Guaido, the president of the National Assembly of Venezuela, who is trying to oust socialist leader Mr Maduro.The European Union on Thursday recognised Mr Guaido as interim president in place of Mr Maduro, with Mr Hunt calling for sanctions against the latter. The United States has also recognised his leadership.The future of Venezuela is a matter for Venezuelans. @Jeremy_Hunts call for more sanctions on Venezuela is wrong. We oppose outside interference in Venezuela, whether from the US or anywhere .There needs to be dialogue and a negotiated settlement to overcome the crisis.mdash Jeremy CorbynFebruary , But in a Friday tweet, Mr Corbyn said: ldquoThe future of Venezuela is a matter for Venezuelans. Jeremy Huntrsquos call for more sanctions on Venezuela is wrong.ldquoWe oppose outside interference in Venezuela, whether from the US or anywhere .ldquoThere needs to be dialogue and a negotiated settlement to overcome the crisis.Other senior Labour frontbenchers have also criticised the pressure being put on Mr Maduro, who is widely seen as a dictator, accusing the US of attempting ldquoregime change.Shadow chancellor John McDonnell, shadow home secretary Diane Abbott and shadow justice secretary Richard Burgon were among a host of left-wing politicians, union leaders and activists who signed a letter to the Observer on Sunday.It said: ldquoWhatever views people hold on Venezuela, there is no justication for backing the US attempt at regime change under way, which,successful, could go the way of the disastrous interventions in Iraq and Libya.ldquoInstead, the way forward is the call for dialogue from the Mexican and Bolivian presidents.Mr Cox resigned from Save the Children in September , amid allegations of inappropriate behaviour towards women.His we Jo, the MP for Batley and Spen in Yorkshire, was assassinated by neo-Nazi killer Thomas Mair in June .

their show back on the road again.The golden voice of Stockholm-based Scot Andrew Montgomery was one of the key things that set them apart from former label-mates Suede, with whom they were often compared.While he may look nervous between some songs, when the gaps were a little longer than he might have wished, it did not show in his choirboy croon.Guitarist Steven Dora is pleased to havethe lies the story of one of Scotlands most underrated bands who, perhaps, never really themselves fully appreciated just what made them so special.East Kilbride-raised Montgomery says it was through social media, and the love shown through that medium that convinced the band that they would reunite."I kept in touch with some of the guys on and off, and there was the possibility of doing something and you just end up going,why not  After years and years, you go I cant do that because it would be getting on a bandwagon, or something like that."But it is the power of social media. You wouldnt believe the people that contact you that are perfect strangers over the music. And they dont give up playing the music."People say they will always think fondly of Geneva and people say you guys could have gone on to do great things."So it is the power of suggestion, really. But he adds, they will be back.

title: thief-struck-at-101-store-in-castlemilk-arcade
story: Police said the man, who had a kne, threatened two staff members in the  store in the Castlemilk Arcade on Thursday night.He escaped with a two figure sum of cash and a  pack of Budweiser beer.The robber is described as being white, of stocky build and was wearing a grey tracksuit top with the hood up, a black beanie hat, grey jogging bottoms with black socks over them, and white trainers.Detective Constable Mark McCallum said: ldquoThe suspect was loitering around outside the store for several minutes before he entered and I would appeal to anyone who saw him to please get in touch.ldquoI would also like to speak to anyone who noticed a man matching the above description carrying a -pack of Budweiser beer in the area to come forward, as well as asking motorists with dash-cams who were in the vicinity of Castlemilk Drive to check their footage, in case they have captured anything which could be of signicance to our investigation."Call  with any information.

title: thief-ransacked-her-bedroom-in-clydebank
story: Police said the -year-old ed to her flat in Milton Mains Court, in Clydebank, Glasgow, on Thursday when she saw the man, with a clipboard, entering the close behind her.Her door went shortly afterwards and she opened it to find the man standing there, claiming to be from the water board. He said there was a problem with her drains and requested access inside.She let him inside and he distracted her in the kitchen while a younger man, seen outside with the other man, entered her home and ransacked her bedroom. He took a four figure sum of money from her purse.The elderly victim realised what had happened after the man left and contacted the police.The first suspect is described as being in his s, of stocky build and wearing a fawn coloured hat, light coloured clothing and work boots.The second suspect is described as being a younger man.Detective Sergeant Fiona Macarthur from Clydebank CID said: ldquoThis was a despicable crime which has left an elderly woman extremely upset and without a signicant sum of money.ldquoIt is absolutely vital that we trace these abhorrent iniduals and I would appeal to anyone who noticed men matching the above descriptions loitering in the area, or even answered the door to one of them, to please get in touch.ldquoI would also urge people to be extra vigilant and ensure elderly relatives and neighbours are aware of the dangers of letting people into their homes without verying their identity."Call  with any information.

title: bins to be collected once every three weeks in new council strategy
story: Aberdeenshire residents will be encouraged to become recycling champions with the introduction of a controversial three-weekly collection programme.The revised waste strategy for all , properties in the Shire was approved in a - vote by the council’s Infrastructure Services Committee despite an alternative option from Peterhead SNP councillor Stephen Smith who said it was “too much, too soon”.From April next year, households will have weekly kerbside collections for one of three bins including a  litre bin for paper and card and  litre bin for metals, plastics and cartons.However under the new scheme, the existing general residual bin for non-recyclable waste will be signicantly reduced to a  litre capacity.Councillors were told by waste director Philip McKay that while it was a considerable reduction, the service felt it “should be manageable for most households”.He added that while a three-weekly non-recyclable waste collection might feel a bit daunting to residents initially – as did the move from weekly to fortnightly collections in Aberdeenshire a few years ago – experience from other Scottish local authorities showed that it is workable and can lead to a signicant increase in recycling rates.Mr McKay also stressed that given the larger recycling capacity provided in the favoured option, it provided “more flexibility in the future” for the addition of other recyclable materials without the need for additional recycling containers.Councillors were told that the scheme had the potential to save waste services £, per year at the lower end of the scale and even morethere was a higher uptake in recycling.However, Peterhead councillor Stephen Smith said the proposals as they stood were a step too far for North-east communities.In a bid to address concerns about the potential impact of any necessary changes to the waste strategy, he proposed that instead of using a -litre bin for three weekly collections, Aberdeenshire Council instead do what has happened in much of the rest of Scotland and keep the  litre bin for three weekly waste collections, with new  litre bins – which are expected to be funded in large part by ‘Zero Waste Scotland’ – being used for paper and card recycling for a transitional period.Councillor Smith’s proposal – which he claimed would have saved an estimated £, annually – followed confirmation from council officers that such a proposal would be compatible with Zero Waste Scotland’s requirements for helping to fund the cost of the new bins required.But council depute leader Peter Argyle warned against “changing horses” halfway through the programme as it would only lead to confusion.He told the committee that with an imminent landfill ban on biodegradable waste “coming down the tracks” by , it was title: entertainers mark ten years of business
story: Ellon-based company Lisa Lollipop Entertainers is celebrating ten years of business.Lisa Lollipop provides entertainment for children at private parties, nursery schools, hospital and corporate events across the north east.Private parties currently represent the core market for the Lollipop Entertainers business.These parties are held in community centres, sports halls and customers’ homes.The Lollipop team have visited almost every village hall and community centre across Aberdeenshire.They’ve also been welcomed into many families’ homes to celebrate special moments in their lives from celebrating baby’s first birthday, right through to pre-teen and then continuing to mark special family fun birthdays and events.The business has developed over the years and can now entertain party sizes in excess of  children.Party games, face painting, balloon modelling, baby parties, soft play, pre-teen discos and superhero princess characters are offered.Lisa Lollipop employees take on the appearance and persona of the fairy-tale ‘Lollipop’ character and superhero princess characters.Since the business started up in , the Lisa Lollipop character has gained a strong following and achieved high brand recognition.Lisa Lollipop has active social media pages, ‘How to’ balloon modelling films on YouTube, an active newsletter and has entertained at over , parties equating to over , local children having met Lisa Lollipop.Lisa Mann, owner of Lisa Lollipop Entertainers said: “I couldn’t have asked for a more exciting and creative way to spend my time, everyday doing something I have loved from the moment I started, ten years ago.“I certainly didn’t think I would be fortunate enough to have continued with my dream job for this long.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse
