title: mackie s offers sweet take on burns night scran
story: Back by popular demand, Mackies of Scotland is relaunching its limited edition haggis and marmalade ice cream for Burns Night.The handcrafted speciality recipe – which has been made on the firms Westertown family farm – is available all weekend at Mackie’s . parlour in Aberdeen.The Burns Night treat will be available all weekendAt am this morning, piper Robert Reid from Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band piped the haggis ice cream in to the Marischal Square parlour.The ice cream has been made with Scotland’s famous Hall’s haggis, and has orange marmalade swirled through the mix.In celebration of Scotland’s Ploughman Poet, customers at . will be given free samples of the experimental dessert – and those who play a tune on the bagpipes will be able to enjoy any free scoop of their choice.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at Mackie’s ., said: “While Marmalade is not a traditional accompaniment for Haggis – we added a ripple to help make this Scottish delicacy a little tastier when served cold in ice cream. And, of course a nip of whisky can also be drizzled over the top to raise a cone to the Bard.“Our haggis ice cream was such a hit last year that we just had to bring it back for Burns Night . Since last year’s limited edition batch, we’ve had people visit the parlour specically to try the flavour. So this weekend is the perfect opportunity for those who didn’t get the chance the first time round to satisfy their curiosity – and their taste buds.”Mackie’s is encouraging the public to share their thoughts on the creation with the hashtag #taemackiesicecream.Yvette added: “We love experimenting with our flavours at Mackie’s, and in celebration of Burns we’re challenging everyone to step outside their comfort zone, and try a scoop of our latest creation."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Pensioners injuries were "worst" Detective had ever seenviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory Ball viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: thainstone goes electric
story: ANM Group has installed electric vehicle charging facilities at Thainstone Centre as part of its green strategy and wide-ranging customer service offering.Charging an electric vehicle at the site will be free to all users for the next  months.ANM Group received funding from Transport Scotland, through a programme managed by the Energy Saving Trust private organisations can apply for grant support to install a publicly-available charging points through Transport Scotland’s ChargePlace Scotland project.Home-owners who own or use an electric or plug-in car can also apply for grant support towards the installation of a home charging unit.Grant Rogerson, Chief Executive at ANM Group, said: “We are pleased to partner with Transport Scotland by installing four electric vehicle charge points at Thainstone. “The centre is located just off the A and is a natural choice for the charging points, with a large car park and an award-winning restaurant on site, it has all the necessary amenities for drivers and passengers.“The charge points have the capability of charging up to eight vehicles at one time, and will certainly benefit the local community and those travelling.“The project is in line with our green strategy and supports our business objective of increasing our services to our members, customers and the local community.“We look forward to welcoming all visitors and invite them to see what our centre has to offer.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Murder trial jury to consider verdict viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: travelling after brexit how it impacts data roaming and driving abroad
story: It could be you have concerns aboutyour flight will still take off or what you need to doyou are driving in Europe.Travel company First Choice and ABTA, the leading association of travel agents and tour operators, have released details in a bid to help travellers.Will flights still go evena deal isnrsquot reached First Choice said: ldquoWe know that flights taking off in the UK will still be permitted to fly within the European Unionrsquos airspace, even it a deal isnrsquot reached - thatrsquos been confirmed by the European Commission.ldquoEvenwe have a no-deal Brexit, flights between the UK and the EU will still take place as normal. Even when a deal is decided, nothing will happen overnight - wersquoll go into a period of transition for two years up until late .Read more: What will Brexit mean for you and your family  What aboutIm driving while on holiday For those that choose to drive abroad ABTA says that those with a full UK driving licence may need to apply for a relevant International Driving Permit.These cost £. and are available directly from the Post Office - the RAC and AA will not be issuing them from February .There are two IDPs depending on which country you are visiting - drivers travelling between dferent countriesmay need both types.ABTA said: ldquoThe Government is working to extend the network of Post Offices where you can apply for an International Driving Permit, and has plans to roll these out in more branches across the UK from  February .ldquoCheck carefully which permit is required for each country you intend to drive within, as you may need more than one permit to comply with the law.You may also need a green card. title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeSaturday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: airports chairwoman is appointed
story: IT HAS been announced by Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson MSP, that Lorna Jack had been appointed as chairwoman of the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , operators of several airports, including Kirkwall Airport.Ms Jack is a chartered accountant and a graduate of Aberdeen University. She joined the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited as a non-executive director in March  and chaired its Audit Committee for over three years, until she was invited to take on the interim chair role in October .Ms Jack remains the chief executive of the Law Society of Scotland and is an independent member of the Court of University of Aberdeen and a member of its Governance and Nominations Committee. story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding folk that their Christmas tree collection service for households on the Orkney mainland, within mph areas only, will get underway from Monday next week.The title: featured property of the week 5
story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. The large rear garden has mature trees and bushes, making the garden area extremely sheltered and private. There is also a patio area and garden shed.Viewing is highly recommended to fully appreciate all that this property has to offer.The Home Report is available by email on request.For further information and to arrange a viewing, please contact Kerry Croy Tel:  . title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Bid for 60k funding as Dingwalls Puffin Pool limps along
story: AN urgent pound, fundraising campaign to enable essential repairs at an ailing hydrotherapy pool used by thousands of people suffering painful or disabling conditions has been launched.The charity-run Puffin Pool in Dingwall has been forced to close its doors on several occasions and is currently ldquolimping along, says its board which is urging people to support an appeal to keep it open.It provides specialist therapy to adults and children with conditions affecting their joints, bones, muscles or neurological system and is also used to help speed up rehabilitation after accidents and operations.But the pool has had to close several times due to the failure of the air handling unit.Board member Barbara Manson said it needed a major overhaul including a new ultra violet system for the water purication system and replacement entrance doors.ldquoIt is limping along until we can get new equipment, she said. ldquoItrsquos the fact the pool is  years old and everything is beginning to break down. We are also very aware there needs to be some internal structural alterations.Given the urgency, the board is using its capital reserves to order the new air handling unit which is should be installed in March.ldquoIf the equipment breaks down between now and then, the pool will have to close, Mrs Manson said. ldquoSome people attend the pool on a weekly basis and that is what keeps them going. If it has to close for a number of weeks, it can make a real dference to their mobility and pain control.Retired GP Helen Charley, board chairman, said:ldquoHaving been a GP in Cromarty for  years, and having needed both hips and knees replaced, I am all too aware of how vital the Puffin Pool is to the good health and wellbeing of so many patients like me, she said.Established in  by Dr Malcolm Stevens, the pool has provided an average , sessions each year over the past four years. They are supervised by qualied supervisors and leguards.The majority of income is from its charity shop In Tulloch Street and the fees which are kept affordable for those on benefits, pensions and low incomes although these have increased by  per cent.Supporters are rallying to support the appeal and staff plan a -mile sponsored walk from Tain to Dingwall.To donate, see www.puffinpool or pop in to the pool or shop.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Blind Strathpeffer mum set to see her first book published
story: A STRATHPEFFER mum struck blind by diabetes has written a childrenrsquos book after being snapped up by a London publisher.Emily Grayrsquos paperback, Priscilla the Pig, was inspired by her mother Heatherrsquos childhood stories at Woodlands Farm in Dingwall.The -year-old University of Highlands and Islands literature student lost her sight after being diagnosed with Type  diabetes. ldquoIt came as a shock because there was no family history of diabetes, she said.Ultimately she could no longer walk around without help ndash a massive shock to the system.Forced to drop her music studies degree course at Edinburghrsquos Napier University, she admitted the experience was ldquohorric.Getting help from Sight Action ldquowas a massive help. Guide dog April came into her le and the following year she gave birth to her first child, Harris.During pregnancy she mused over her own childhood settled into writing her first story using a voiceover computer programme. Itrsquos illustrated by self-taught Nairn artist Sarah Jane Cumberford.The full-time mum has a lot on her plate and now relies on her main sense of hearing.She said: ldquoLuckily Irsquove got a very noisy little boy. Itrsquos easy to keep track of him. I can generally tellhersquos getting up to no good.A former pupil of Strathpeffer Primary and Dingwall Academy, she said: ldquoIrsquom on a mission to show people that itrsquos not the end of the world and you can still achieve anything you want. ldquoEmilyrsquos book is published by Olympia Publisherson Thursday under her pen name, Madeline Rose.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Check your cold weather payment eligibility says Ross MP as temperature plummets
story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. For many years this was set at pound. a week but the LabourGovernment increased the rate to pound a week as a temporary measure for winters - and -. In , the Coalition Government made the pound rate permanent.Payments should be made automatically to those entitled to them there should be no need to make a claim.However concerns have previously been raised that payments can be missed and Mr Blackford believes it is important that people, who believe that they may be eligible follow this through, particularly as the cold weather bites.He said: ldquoWe have been experiencing quite a prolonged period of cold and wet weather in the Highlands and Islands. It is hugely important that anyone eligible for a cold weather payment receives it. It can really make a dference to a vulnerable person or family who is experiencing high heating costs.ldquoThese payments should be made to eligible iniduals automatically, however, in my experience that is not always the case. I would urge anyone who believes that they may be due a payment to contact their nearest Job Centre Plus and get what they are owed.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Evanton project branches out with new building
story: COUPLES looking to tie the knot amidst naturersquos splendour will soon have a quirky new wedding venue to consider thanks to a major feat of engineering currently taking place within an Easter Ross woodland.The building currently under construction in Mags Wood near Evanton will also provide an ideal location for yoga sessions for those keen to get back to nature as well as ceilidhs and other community celebrations.Being carried out under the auspices of Evanton Community Woods, the building project may well result in the UKrsquos biggest freestanding reciprocal roofed structure, a simple, strong self-supporting technique perfect for round buildings.Simon Harry, education co-ordinator at Evanton Community Woods, explained how he had been aware of the need for another building within the woodland to provide the many groups already visiting the area more space within which to carry out their activities.He said: ldquoWe aim to run workshops such as green woodworking and outdoor learning from the space along as well as offering it to local groups such as guides and scouts to use for overnight expeditions.ldquoWe have also held a number of weddings in the woods and this would be a perfect location once completed.ldquoThe main driver for the project is that we are also training folk in the unique skills of log building, to share the skills. We have worked with local volunteers, school groups, young offenders, dementia groups, local walking groups and adult learners.In tune with the sustainable development ethos of the group, logs for Mags Wood build have been sourced locally and dragged to the site by Tarzan, a French-bred horse trained for forestry operations ndash and something of a visitor attraction in himself, hugely popular with the school groups who visit the site from time to time.The building project has been able to call on the expertise of local log building expert Henry Fosbrooke, project co-ordinator David Smith and a local volunteer, Don Fraser, who previously worked on the new Queensferry next to the Forth Road Bridge.Mr Harry said that such expertise ldquohas meant that all the measurements done are near perfect.The project has been funded by the Forestry Commission through a community grant amongst ious other sources.Mr Harry said: ldquoThis will be something special for the area and is involving many iniduals and groups in its building ndash truly a community project and something that will last a very, very long time.He is still hoping to find a supplier willing to help with the timber roof cladding required to complete the project, hopefully by the end of March. That would involve around  m x mm larch planks. The alternative will be to process locally sourced timber from the site.Anyone interested in becoming involved or who can help out can contact Simon Harry by email at simon.harry@forest-education or by calling  .Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ex pat never forgot native Black Isle
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a former Black Isle man who died at home after battling an illness for several years.Although he moved to Hannibal in Missouri in the s, Kenneth Macdonald, who was born in Fortrose in , retained a lasting interest in his home town, following events from afar through the hugely popular Fortrose and Rosemarkie Past and Present Facebook page.Mr Macdonald shared with that grouprsquos leading light, John Mackenzie, a great interest in motor sports and owned two lovely classic cars, a Triumph TR and a Corvette.Mr Mackenzie said he had decided to use the page to share news of the former Fortrose manrsquos death with others who might have known him. His father ran the family businesses, a coal merchant and a plasterers business in Fortrose.Mr Mackenzie said: ldquoKen ed to his home following a y stay in hospital.ldquoHe was delighted to sit in his own home and in his favourite chair and even smoked a cigarette. Irsquom sure that many of you will join me in offering our sincere condolences to his two daughters Mhairi and Katie and to their families.Mr Macdonaldrsquos late we, Susan, passed away in .During his early years in Fortrose, his budding talents emerged. He studied civil engineering at Edinburgh University and won a bursary to further his studies in the United States at Washington University in St Louis. It was in the States he met his we Susan whom he married in .Mr Macdonald also spent time during a distinguished engineering career in Benbecula during a period when the couple had moved to Edinburgh. There he was working with a contractor who in turn worked for the Ministry of Defence.His elder daughter Mhairi was born during the time they lived in Benbecula.After Benbecula the family moved to Hannibal where Mr Macdonald continued to work as an engineer.He was resident engineer with the Missouridepartment of transportationoverseeing the building of the Mark Twain Memorial Bridge across the Mississippi in the late s.Mr Macdonald continued toto Fortrose when possible but failing health over the past number of years meant that it was no longer possible.His passion for the place he grew up during his formative years was kindled by the local photographs posted on a regular basis on the Facebook page, ranging from present-day scenes to some more nostalgic images.He was also a member of the Hannibal Loafers car club.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Hopes for future of shelved Dingwall fish factory
story: HOPES are high another manufacturer will swoop into Dingwall and start afresh in the building being vacated by the Edinburgh Salmon Company .The base where  people lost their jobs at the end of last month is on sale for an undisclosed sum.Dingwall councillor Margaret Paterson believes the vast majority of the laid off workers will stay put in Dingwall in the hope another venture will open soon.She said: ldquoMany of those people have lived in Dingwall for years and years theyrsquove got staying power, theyrsquore hard workers. Theyrsquove got homes here, their children go to school here theyrsquove made Dingwall their home. You donrsquot leave your home without putting up a really hard fight.Fellow ward councillor Alister Mackinnon understands several companies have been eyeing-up the building but doubts the scale of any future fish processing organisation would match ESCorsquos operation.A spokesman for the firm, which opened in Dingwall in , said: ldquoWe are exploring all possible avenues regarding a potential sale of the facilities.It would not ulge further details, citing commercial sensitivity. Around  workers have been kept on to carry out decommissioning.Before the December closure, more than  people attended a jobs fair in Dingwall Town Hall. Employers in attendance included Stagecoach, Tesco, Marine Harvest, High Le Highland and Highland Council.Highland Council hoped to fill at least some of the  vacant jobs it pitched to the stricken fish workers. Roles included teachers, a social worker, drivers, school cleaners and cooks and a catering area supervisor.It was estimated by Skills Development Scotland, which steered the event, that  jobs were on offer.Kate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, said: ldquoThe jobs fair was very successful in terms of attracting a lot of interested employees.ldquoOf course it was a dficult period for them but I hope that the training providers and employers opened up new opportunities for them.ldquoI have had correspondence from at least one attendee since the event.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Impressive turnout for Dingwalls new U3A group
story: THE inaugural meeting of a University of the Third Agegroup in Dingwall drew more than  people.The group brings allows people to learn with like-minded folk by creating interest groups and sharing skills and knowledge. It also organises monthly talks of general interest and provides a  for socialising and making contacts.Dingwall and District UA, part of a national movement, will host regular talks, the next of which is on Thursday, February  in The Baptist Church Hall, Tulloch Street, Dingwall at pm.It will be addressed by bridge builder Don Fraser MBE whose last project was construction of the Queensferry Crossing.The organisation has proved a hit in particular with retired people interest in learning new things in their own time with like-minded folk. Interest groups can have as few as two people in them.Last weekrsquos meeting in Dingwall was addressed by Ed Link, Third Age Trustee for Scotland and Linda Clark, Third Age Trust Volunteer.The group has a web site at https:uasites.org.uk dingwall home and a presence on Facebook.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Muir of Ord pupils go purple for inspirational Beth
story: BIG-hearted pupils at a Ross-shire school showed their true colours in a poignant show of solidarity with an inspiratinal "one in a million" classmate suffering from a rare condition.Tarradale Primary pupil Beth Cameron was diagnosed with chronic recurring multocal osteomyelitis , a rare condition affecting around one in a million children in which the bones have lesions, inflammation and pain.Classmates decided to show their support for Beth by inviting pupils to wear something purple last Friday ndash whether that be ribbon, socks, t-shirt or jumper. Beth was greeted by a sea of purple when she turned up at school.Head teacher Tracy Sinclair took to Facebook to explain to parents: "Our perfect Beth is blazing a trail. We talked a lot about barriers to learning and le. Sleeping in. Days off. Lateness. When all the while we have umpteen pupils with so many barriers including severe pain in here every day at nine orsquoclock rain, hail or shine! Wow! Just wow! Our children will tell you spice makes le more interesting! Tolerance and understanding of every human condition makes the world a better place. Your children are trailblazers!"Sheila Scott responded in kind, writing: "So proud of our beautul granddaughter and cant believe how brave and understanding she has been this last  months going through all the pain, tests etc till CRMO was diagnosed and now making others aware of her diagnosis. Always with big smiles and caring for others."Ms Sinclair said: "We agree wholeheartedly. Shersquos a true inspiration."Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: New homes planned for Dingwall
story: DINGWALL moved a step closer to getting  new homes after the Ross and Cromarty area committee agreed an infrastructure investment ldquounlocking the possibility of the development.But councillors were at odds over the plans with some considering them a sop in lieu of the  homes earmarked for the town since  while others said it was a ldquopositive move in a high pressure area for housing demand.The original plan was based on the delivery of the Kinnairdie Link Roadproject ndash expected to unleash millions in inward investment. It was due to start its final phase of construction this year but it was axed from the councilrsquos capital programme in last yearrsquos budget.Then in March, funding for transport improvements in Dingwall was found to enable some housing development to take place prior to the commencement of the KLR.A transport study and modelling work considered the impact of ious levels of development in the town and improvements will include work at the Bridgend Avenue Junction and Docharty Road Junction as well as traffic signal works at Mart Road Junction. Proposals for walking and cycling improvements and traffic management measures will also be brought forward to enhance active travel facilities in the town.Dingwall and Seaforth councillor Graham Mackenzie said: ldquoIt would be tempting to see it as a good news story for Dingwall. That is not the case. Had we been given what we were promised in an earlier iteration of the capital plan we could be releasing up to  houses for development instead of around ."Instead the KLR was taken out of the capital plan even though the first phase of the project had already started. If Dingwall is to grow and provide the range of housing which is required, the KLR must be moved up the list of priorities. This project needs to be reinstated.Fellow ward councillor Angela Maclean insisted the deal was good news. She said: ldquoWe as councillors have a leadership role and it is up to us to be helping our communities to move forward and this report has examples of when officers have looked for solutions to get round some of the fact that we donrsquot have all the money we would like."Whether it is through the infrastructure road plans or capital fund we are going to try and move forward with these houses in Dingwall, because Dingwall is a pressurised area ndash this is a positive move because we donrsquot have enough houses in Dingwall.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Tain hub and Picture House project progress to come under spotlight
story: Tain and District Development Trusthas already been successful in raising well over pound, towards its projects and secured three employed positions for the local area.On Thursday, February the group is staging a community consultation in the towns Duthac Centre at pm.TDDTs Sarah Mackenzie said: "Weve worked hard to gain a closer relationship with local businesses and groups within Tain and district in order to increase our social and economic impact to the local area making us more attractive to potential funders and investors."To date we have bid and successfully received funding for ourselves and partner projects from FirstPort, Highlands and Islands Enterprise, SSE Beatrice Wind Farm, Beinn Tharsuinn Wind farm Trust and Highland Council."With these funds we are now in a position to employ a community fund manager, business development manager and an administrator to help take our projects to the next level and increase our community-wide benefit. We hope to have these positions filled by early spring."The funds will also allowTDDT to fit out its new community enterprise hub on Stafford Street inTain.Said Ms Mackenzie: "The hub will be the cornerstone to all of our projects as well as providing a space that caters to the wider community offering conferencing facilities, meeting rooms, hot desking andpop-up phops. We hope to be open for business in March this year."Highlands and Islands Enterpriseis providing funding support towards the cost of developing the hub and recruiting a manager.Stewart Wardlaw, HIE Development Manager, Inner Moray Firth area, said: "The Hub will provide valuable business services locally, for commercial and social enterprises."It will also help facilitate the use of business premises within the local community and in a town centre location. This will help make the Tain district a more attractive option for businesses and drive growth locally."We are very pleased to be able to provide support and look forward to seeing the project develop.Through the SSE Beatrice Wind Farm Fund, TDDThas received funds to cover the costs for a full business plan and feasibility study towards the Picture House project.Along with Tain Heritage Trust and Tain and Easter Ross Civic Trust,TDDT hasalready managed to successfully clear the outside of the premises andtidy up inside,allowing the community a rare glimpse of a building through photographs thatmany hold close to their hearts.The Beatrice Partnership Fund said it wasdelighted to support the community withits aspirations to restorethe iconic local building.Tain Heritage Trusts Chairman David Robertson welcomed the support theyve had in recent months from Tain  Easter Ross Civic Trust and from Tain  District Development Trust to help kick-start the Picture House redevelopment.He said: "This help has now secured us funding for a feasibilitystudy from SSE.We welcome the involvement of SSE in what really would be a transformational project for the town."Lets hope this is the start of a fruitful partnership with them to secure the phased restoration of our Royal Burghs much-loved hall. Our town can only prosper when groups work together for the CommonWeal. Thats what we are seeing with the Development Trust. Long may it continue."Tain and Easter Ross Civic Trust says it is proud to be playing a signicant role in the restoration of this building dating from  it is one of the finest works of the Maitland firm of architects who designed so many of the Victorian and Edwardian buildings that form such an important part of Tains heritage.Hamish Mackenzie of the Trust said: "It played a major role in the le of Tain, first as a public hall and then from  s as a cinema and we hope to see it resuming to its former glory in the st century."The community consultation on Thursday in the Duthac Centre at pm will give people a chance to see the development made so far as well as having their say on future developments.Member votes will required to make amendments to our constitution in order to progress the Picture House Project and to secure larger funds and investments.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: cash return on cards as sse sells wind farm stakes for 635m
story: Perth-based power giant SSE is to sell a stake in two major Scottish wind farms for # million to help fund a programme to buy back shares from investors.The utility group has agreed to sell a . per cent holding in its Stronelairg and Dunmaglass wind farms to Greencoat UK Wind in partnership with a major UK pension fund.Stronelairg, which has  wind turbines, is located near Fort Augustus and has an installed generating capacity of  megawatts. It was commissioned in December.Dunmaglass, meanwhile, is located  miles south of Inverness and has an installed generating capacity of  megawatts from  turbines.SSE said that up to £m of the proceeds will be used to fund the share buy-back programme with the remainder used to reduce the group’s debt.The £m consideration equals to around £m per megawatts generated by the wind farms, which SSE will continue to operate.The deal is in line with the company’s strategy announced last November to sell stakes in its portfolio of onshore and offshore wind farms in order to create value from development and operation, as well as ownership, of assets.Greencoat UK Wind said it had entered into agreements to acquire the . per cent stakes in the wind farms from SSE, in partnership with the UK pension fund whose investment is managed by Greencoat Capital. Greencoat UK Wind is raising up to £m.Gregor Alexander, SSE’s finance director, said: “Both Stronelairg and Dunmaglass are a testament to SSE’s ability to design, develop, construct and operate first-class renewable energy assets. Onshore wind makes a huge contribution to supplying low carbon electricity to the GB market and to meeting the UK’s carbon reduction targets.“The sale of stakes in these wind farms to Greencoat is a continuation of SSE’s longstanding approach of partnering and securing value for shareholders at appropriate times.”Laurence Fumagalli of Greencoat Capital said: “We are pleased to add two more large wind farm investments to our portfolio, located close to our existing capacity in the Highlands. We continue to see a strong pipeline of acquisition opportunities, and our independence and our proven track record in execution and operations makes us an attractive partner for utility vendors looking to recycle capital.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit jeremy corbyn s strategy is a gift to the snp ayesha hazarika
story: Many Labour activists in Scotland have their head in their hands, fearing the party may end up appearing to be colluding with the Tories over Brexit, writes Ayesha Hazarika.The Westminster bubble is real. But when I was in Parliament on Tuesday, when MPs voted on a raft of Brexit amendments, it felt like many MPs were living in their very own micro-bubbles – particularly on the Labour side. There are as many Labour positions on Brexit as there are Labour MPs. Those in leave-voting seats have a tough gig. They are trying to listen to their constituents and listen to their gut instincts about what they think is best for the country. Who they are not listening to is their leader.For a man famed for such clarity on many other issues, Jeremy Corbyn has played an elusive game on Brexit. The Labour position is still unclear to many and Labour MPs have decided to do what the Fleetwood Mac song says: “You can go your own way.”Although the Labour leadership eventually supported the key Yvette Cooper amendment to delay Brexit, it was very late in the day and that sent a signal that it was a soft whip. The Labour MPs who defied the whip or abstained and helped a beleaguered Prime Minister secure that vital Brexit win won’t even get put on the naughty step.: Brexit: Ireland warning over ‘threats’ as EU rejects May’s dealLabour loyalists are relaxed about Theresa May’s victory. It’s all still a shambles, they say, which is an absolutely fair point. The Labour plan seems to be don’t block Brexit, let the Tories own the chaos, chillax until the General Election then romp home to victory. Simples!Well, not quite. Many Labour strategists seem to have forgotten that Labour cannot win a majority without winning seats in Scotland. The obsession with Labour votes in the North of England has meant that the rather large, cold place north of that has been somewhat forgotten.A large majority of people in Scotland voted to remain. Many hate austerity and want more radical, socialist economic policies but also think staying in the EU is the best option – angry Corbynistas take note, it is possible to hold those two positions and not be a traitor.Many Labour activists in Scotland have their head in their hands. They are desperately worried that Labour may end up doing a deal with Mrs May, be seen to be colluding with the Tories and being on the wrong side of the Scottish people. And Brexit is coming up the doorstep.: Brexit: Barclays given green light to transfer £bn to IrelandOne activist told me that it’s not the first thing people mention but when they get onto it, they cannot believe what is playing out in London and are following it closely. There is anger on all sides. It has confirmed the belief that the Tories don’t care about Scotland, but there is resentment and confusion about Labour’s position, especially on why it won’t support another referendum.There is, of course, one political winner in Scotland as a result of the mess in Westminster. One Labour voter summed it up: “There’s no leadership in Westminster – but at least Nicola Sturgeon is showing some.” Now this person was notan SNP or independence supporter but they were a strong remainer.Brexit could transcend party allegiances in Scotland. A two-horse race in England may well benefit Labour but in Scotland, they could find themselves once again painfully squeezed between a remain-supporting SNP and a leave-supporting Tory party. Fudge only gets you so far.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: how brexit may make barbaric urban hunters suddenly popular paris gourtsoyannis
story: A no-deal Brexit may mean allotment holders, anglers and #barbaric# urban hunters suddenly become popular at dinner parties, writes Paris Gourtsoyannis.A bizarre story splashed across the front of the Edinburgh Evening News caught my attention this week.It described how office workers in Granton watched in horror as a group of hunters with dogs stalked and killed a deer, before butchering it in an urban car park. Imagine the shock in the break-out area and the queue for the coffee cart.Barbaric, evil, sickened, was just some of the reaction that flooded in. It’s obviously a serious matteran animal suffered inhumane ­treatment, and police are investigating the incident as a possible illegal deer killing.But after reading, I couldn’t help wonderwhat the .am Scottish Gas team meeting had witnessed was a glimpse of the future.Theresa May is off on a hunt of her own, but her chances of grabbing a unicorn Brexit renegotiation in Brussels are evidently much worse than catching a venison dinner by the side of Lower Granton Road.With the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit rising, supermarkets issued a dramatic warning this week: failure to agree a Brexit deal could choke off nearly nine-tenths of lorry traffic across the Channel, emptying shelves and triggering panic buying.: Armed gang of hunters butcher a deer in GrantonAvoiding hunger will mean ing to the rugged self-sufficiency of Britain’s former meat-and-potatoes diet. One snag: huge export tarfs would likely decimate the UK’s ­livestock industry.So while we have contempt for them now, after a no-deal Brexit we could all be forced to hone our urban ­hunting skills.The shts in social capital in no-deal Brexit Britain will be dramatic. Allotment holders, anglers, weekend mushroom foragers, the archery club president: people you wouldn’t normally want to be seated next to at a dinner party,they were invited at all. From April, the dinner party isn’t happening without them.Online dating would transform, almost overnight. Tinder is filled with gym selfies showing off rippling abs or yoga poses in front of Cambodian sunsets – but that won’t put food on the table. Can you skin a woodland animal  Swipe right. ­Netflix and chill becomes Netflix and roadkill.If Brexit was a lunge for the past by an alienated older generation, they can look forward to reclaiming some fond memories of their childhood. A collapsed pound and gridlocked passport control means European beach trips and city breaks are out – so it will be back with the tattie ­holidays and fruit picking at weekends, for fun, fresh air, and, most importantly, ­calories. After all, there won’t be any foreigners left to do it. : No-deal Brexit ‘would clear Scottish supermarkets of food in two days’DIY will take on new meaning, as back gardens are dug up and ­trampolines repurposed as makesht polytunnels. Internet crime has no romance – bring back orchard thieves.Given the abundance of deer and other roaming foodstuffs, Scotland can look forward to a relatively ­comfortable le in no-deal Brexit Britain. Here in London, the diet will mainly consist of urban fox. Food prices will replace property prices in conversation. “You can get a lot more for your hunting up north, you know.”I look forward to Springwatch becoming a hybrid nature cookery programme, co-hosted by Chris Packham and Ainsley Harriott. What goes with Suzie Salt  Barn owl.The Evening News’ report said the three hunters were last seen carrying the deer carcass – gutted to preserve the meat for consumption and sale – towards a nearby Morrisons. How apt.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: key snp figures told by nicola sturgeon to prepare for possible election
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...SNP parliamentarians have been told by Nicola Sturgeon to prepare for a possible Scottish electionthe government at Holyrood fails to pass its budget today.The Scottish Government heads into today’s vote without a deal to secure a majority, risking defeat on its spending plans for the coming year.During a meeting of the SNP group at Westminster attended by the First Minister on Monday, Ms Sturgeon warned her MPs that they should prepare for a possible Scottish election campaignthe government fails to get its budget through, The Scotsman understands.However the move comes amid speculation that Ms Sturgeon may need a fresh mandate from the electorate to secure another referendum on independence, as she prepares to reveal her plans on the issue. Publicly, the government has stated that it is focused on getting its spending plans passed and is confident of reaching a compromise.In , when an SNP minority government had its budget defeated by the Scottish Parliament, then-First Minister Alex Salmond threatened a snap election before the deadlock was broken.The current SNP minority has struck a more conciliatory tone and sought to calm speculation about an election, with Finance Secretary Derek Mackay last night appealing for MSPs to “act responsibly”.Last ditch talks are set to continue today in the final hours before a vote, with the Green Party holding out for concessions on local government spending and council tax reform.Mr Mackay must secure the support of the six Green MSPs to pass his budget, with all other opposition parties committed to voting against it.Green Party co-convener Patrick Harvie has dismissed suggestions his party could bring down the government by rejecting the SNP’s budget as a “myth”.But senior Nationalist figures were openly speculating about the possibility of an election earlier in the week, with SNP committee convener Gillian Martin warning Green MSP Andy Wightman on social media that voting down the budget could force an election and put a second Scottish independence referendum at risk.“You’ve seen the way the other parties coalesce against us to try and bring down the government,” Ms Martin posted on Twitter. “Since  everything for them is about defeating the pro-Indy Parliament.”She added: “We are at risk of an election that might see pro Indy parties lose seats and put us in a weaker position.”Polls show the SNP remains in the lead in Scottish Parliament voting intention, but that the nationalists have lost ground compared with their performance in the  Holyrood election where they narrowly lost their majority.Scottish Conservative shadow finance secretary Murdo Fraser claimed uncertainty around the budget showed the SNP were “unfit” for government.“The SNP has neglected the day job so badly that it’s now struggling to get the single-biggest responsibility taken care of. Nicola Sturgeon is so resigned to the weakness of her own administration, she’s been forced to rally the troops for another election.“Hers would be the first government in the history of the Scottish Parliament to call an election because it couldn’t pass a budget.“That would be a shameful legacy, and shows just how unfit the Nationalists are for government of any kind.”Scottish Liberal Democrat campaign chair Alex Cole-Hamilton MSP said: “We’ve made clear to the SNP that we want a budget that focuses on education, mental health and local government funding.“If their inability to get a budget through necessitates a new Scottish Parliament election then I have every hope that people in Scotland will want to use that to eject the Nationalists.”A Labour spokesman said “no credible anti-austerity party would propose” the draft budget put forward by the SNP.With no deal last night, Mr Mackay said: “Our spending plans for the coming year contain additional money for schools and hospitals, protecting vital public services and investing in our economy, while also providing stability amid the ongoing uncertainty caused by Brexit. “With that backdrop in mind, there has never been more need for MSPs, of all parties, to act responsibly and not add to that uncertainty.”Mr Mackay added: “We are open to compromise in order to ensure we deliver the Budget that the country expects.” ©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
